region:
None
country:
None
text:
I read alot of reviews on this and just kinda figured either I would really like it or really hate it.  Here's what I did based on other reviews: used 1 tsp minced garlic with the butter, only used about 1 1/3 cups milk and 4 oz. of parmesean (half a container of kraft grated), about 1/4 tsp black pepper and a few grinds of sea salt.  This was the best alfredo I have ever had!!!  I didn't even taste a hint of cream cheese and the sauce turned out smooth and creamy and cheesy!!  I served it with cut up grilled chicken and fettucine.  I LOVED it and so did my boyfriend!! I had some extra sauce so I took it to my friend and she thought it was super delicious!! This will be the only alfredo I make from now on! I hate the jar stuff!  The best advice I can give is to have some patience and the whisk IS A MUST!!  Put the milk in a little at a time and just keep stirring.  Don't use too high of heat and I'm telling you your sauce will turn out perfect!!  Thank you for such a great recipe!

text:
I used light cream cheese and skim milk and it was still excellent.  The recipe states that this makes 4 servings, but I would say that it easily doubled that.  Assuming the 4 servings, using these substitutions drops the calories per serving by 85 and drops the fat by 11.8 grams.  The cholesterol drops by 39 mg. (Well worth doing as it is still excellent.)

userID:

Display Name:
GottaFeedYa!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been making this recipe for several years and still can't get enough of it! It is my husband's favorite dish (in fact, I'm pretty sure this is why he married me!) and he requests it constantly.  The only time I had a problem with separating or a heavy butter flavor was the one time I used real butter instead of margarine.  It still tasted very good, but the flavor was MUCH richer and it was significantly thicker overall.  If you have trouble with the parmesan being too grainy or sticking to the bottom of the pot, try adding it right after mixing in the cream cheese and whisk well.  It will be super thick before adding the milk, but the parmesan will blend better.  If you are worried the 2c milk is too much, try mixing everything together and leaving it on low heat while you boil water for the pasta.  It will thicken alot as it cools too.  Other than that, the only real tweaking that I have done is to always ALWAYS add a healthy dash of oregano.  Other seasonings may come and go, but I find oregano essential for rounding out that Italian flavor. **update** Since a few reviews suggested nutmeg I decided to experiment on what I thought was already perfection and it was definitely worth it!  A good dash or two of nutmeg really adds depth and compliments the oregano too. **more update** For those who say they taste too much cream cheese, make sure you are using the whole 6oz of Parmesan. If you are using enough Parmesan it should become the dominant flavor.

Very good and unlike other reviewers, I did not taste the cream cheese, like in so many other savory dishes that use cream cheese it adds smooth richness to it.  VERY good.  Made alot which I like b/c I was feeding 5 of us.  Served over penne, added chopped fresh tomatoes and basil to mine.  Easy, cheap and comforting, and not super greasy like my other recipe.  I did add a few dashes of nutmeg and parsley, pepper, and more salt to taste once I had tossed it.  Thanks!

BY THE WAY: DON'T rate a recipe if you COMPLETELY change it!!!!  That is extremely unfair and none of us want to hear about how you changed every measurement and dumped a bunch of ingredients in it and thought it was so-so.  Not cool!!

text:
Outstanding. Sublime. Fantastic. I could think of infinite adjectives to describe this sauce becuase its so wonderful. I am generally a traditionalist, but the addition of cream cheese is pure genious. I have never made such a velvety alfredo before.  This is my new standard recipe. I did, however, make the following changes; I used some cream and some milk. I also used more parmesan than called for, and topped it off with some nutmeg and fresh parsley. I have also used this sauce as a base for many other sauces, creamy pesto, garlic and mushroom, creamy basil and tomato, the possibilities are endless.  Thanks very much for a great recipe.

text:
I was highly disappointed and will not make again! With all the rave reviews I was expecting something comparable to the sauces in finer Italian restaurants. To me, this sauce is equal to that of a “fast-food” one.  It tastes too much like a cream cheese sauce, not alfredo. I doctored the sauce up at bit. Try sautéing some garlic, diced ham and fresh peas in a tsp. of butter then add to the sauce before serving over cheese tortellini. The added ingredients made the sauce edible.

text:
Very excellent recipe. So much smoother, creamier, and easier than other alfredo recipes I've tried. I did make a few of my own adjustments; I used 1 cup of cream and 1 cup of milk like a few others suggested, I used nutmeg instead of garlic powder and pepper, and used parmesean and romano cheeses. It was so luxurious, and reheats slightly better than some homemade sauces. Great for tossing with pasta or more substantial items like meat and veggies. Definately a keeper!

text:
We made this for dinner last night.  It was awesome!  My daughter likes it better than my old recipe.  Her boyfriend said it tastes like Olive garden.  I served it with noodles and topped with grilled chicken.  The recipe is easy to make.  The key trcik here is to make the sauce on low heat and add the cheese a little at a time. Do not let it start to boil as the butter will seperate.  We will definitely be using this recipe again.  We made no substitutions but made the recipe exactly as written.  Please help me encourage other Allrecipe reviewers to not rate any recipe lower than 5 stars if they do not follow the recipe exactly.  Why do people make changes to recipes and then rate them 3 stars?  Makes no sense to me.

text:
First of all, don't be surprised if your cream cheese doesn't get smooth before adding the milk. Mine stayed quite granular, but smoothed out as soon as I added the milk. I did add a little nutmeg and that perked it up nicely. My husband is a James Beard award-wining restaurant critic and he enjoyed it, but thought the cream cheese was "a little weird." I called him a Poopy Head and informed him I'd be making it a lot, so he'd better just shut up. I think I have a pretty good palate and thought it was yummy-ummy-umptious. I enjoyed it more than the alfredo sauces at most restaurants and it couldn't be easier. This is a keeper, folks. And can be easily modified to fit your personal preferences.

text:
This recipe is very simple and absolutely delicious! Just some words of wisdom: the sauce thickens as it COOLS not as it gets heated. Please take notice to this as it will save you A LOT of time. If you are heating up your sauce in hopes that it will finally thicken, STOP. Its not going to happen. So turn off the stove, and give yourself a pat on the back; your sauce is perfect, you've done well.

Can we get more stars for this recipe?? :)  I have to admit, I wasn't sure about this recipe and expected a cream cheese taste to it, not only that but I thought 6oz of parm had to be a misprint. text:
Absolutely great, quick and easy!  Made this twice, exactly as recipe states, but the second time I used Parmigiano-Reggiano in place of domestic parmesan.  Do yourself a favor and do the same.  It’s worth spending the extra money on the Reggiano.  Which ever parmesan cheese you decide to use, DO NOT use the stuff in the green can.  It’s just not good.  If you can, make this a day ahead.  Flavor is superior the next day.

text:
No one liked this one.  For starters, real Alfredo sauce (from Alfredo's in Rome, Italy) does NOT have garlic, let alone garlic powder. Cream cheese also adds a strange, unreal tang. Genuine Alfredo sauce uses only butter, cream and freshly grated Parmesan. Simple and incredibly easy. What's hard to understand is, real Alfredo sauce takes little more time to make than this does. Why not just make the real thing?? This looks like Alfredo, but that's the closest it comes.

text:
I have often wondered what the key ingredient to my favorite restaurant alfredo sauce that is always missing in mine and I am fully convinced now that it is the cream cheese. I have never made it this way and am on my way to perfecting the above mentioned! I do prefer fresh garlic, so chopped up two cloves instead of the powder. I also toned down the parmesan flavor a little by adding some mozzerella towards the end. Not a huge parm. fan, so this was powerful, but you can easily play with other Italian cheeses after making it the first time to get an idea what you're dealing with. If you're having problems with it separating, I would have to say you're trying to rush it or have the heat too high. I used the whipped cream cheese because I thought it would melt better and it took a few minutes to come together before I could add the milk, but it did get creamy. It took a good 20 minutes on the right temperature after adding the milk etc. to get it hot and creamy to let the cheese fully melt at a good pace. Not understanding what the complaint with making too much is all about. I poured it over 1 lb. of hot pasta and it stuck perfectly and wasn't too much. I made 2 lbs. after reading the reviews and it was a waste of noodles!
Review:

text:
This is beyond awesome! As I learned from some of the reviews, I used 1 1/2 cups milk (2%). I also kinda estimated the cheese, probably putting in a couple of cups of freshly grated grana padano and pecorino romano. I also used 2-3 cloves of minced fresh garlic, along with a few shakes of garlic powder. White pepper might be more appropriate for appearance's sake, but really doesn't matter--I will never again used jarred sauce! I've always made my red sauce from scratch, but never alfredo.  Thank you for a wonderful recipe!

text:
Okay alfredo sauce.  The measurement for the Parmesan cheese really needs to be in cups rather than weight.  I had a large container of pre-shredded Parmesan, so I had to guess at how much was needed based on adding a little and tasting, then adding more until it tasted "right".  At the end, I added a splash of white wine, which really helped.  I probably won't use this as my regular alfredo sauce recipe, but if I'm desperate for alfredo in a hurry, this will work.

Excellent & very easy sauce.  I chose to use a double boiler instead of direct.  I also added about a cup of shredded low fat mozzarella.  I cooked whole wheat penne pasta & after draining, tossed that with 2 cups of diced leftover roasted chicken and 1 cup of leftover green peas.  The alfredo sauce I poured over the pasta mixture in an oven proof casserole. Baked at 375 for about 20 minutes to just toast the top.  My husband says this is an absolute favorite from now on.

text:
Excellent recipe and soooo delicious! I scaled it back to one serving and it made enough for at least 2 people! I used Land O'Lakes Light Butter, a store brand (Publix) light cream cheese, fat free milk and Kraft (green bottle) parm cheese, which made it a little healthier. ;) You HAVE to stir constantly or it won't get thick and creamy. Next time I will try grating fresh parm cheese.  This was one of the best Alfredo sauces I have ever had and I will definitely be making this again soon!

text:
I love this alfredo sauce. I think next time, I will add fresh minced garlic instead of adding the garlic powder. I also used skim milk (it was all I had on hand). Plus, I think the skim milk made the suace a bit less fattening then called for. Using skim milk did not ruin the texture of the sauce at all. It turned out very thick and creamy - just how I like it. I also used low fat cream cheese. I'm very health conscious! I also lowered the heat to low while I cooked my shrimp, broccoli, and spinach to go as a side. I then poured the entire suace into my pot of linguine pasta. Then, I topped it off with my shrimp+veggie mixture. This turned out superb. Protein, fat, and carbs all in one dish. I will make this again, though not any time soon since it is so high in fat.

country:
None
text:
This is my all-time-favorite "allrecipes" recipe (and I have lots!). I've been making this for a few years now and my husband wouldn't complain if we had it for dinner every night. When I make it, I use a bit less butter (around 1/3 cup), an additional 2 tsp. garlic (or to taste), and a few pinches of nutmeg. I keep adding and tasting, until I can taste a hint of the nutmeg. Try it... it makes all of the difference! It will taste like Olive Garden's... only better. I also usually roast a clove of garlic in the oven and add the roasted cloves to the sauce. If your alfredo is too runny, keep adding parmesan until you get a consistency you like. Goes perfect with bruschetta.

Rating:

userID:
762587
Display Name:
MSALLIED
isPro:

followersCount:
1

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614254.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
When another Alfredo recipe from this site flopped because my heavy cream turned out to be past its prime (whoops!) I ran back online and grabbed this recipe because I always have cream cheese on hand.  At first I was scared because the butter and cream cheese looked curdled in the pot, but as soon as I added some milk, it smoothed right out.

This sauce was delicious and I will most definitely make this again.  I recommend using fresh garlic instead of the powdered stuff.  And I also found that this worked out perfectly well using low fat cream cheese and 1% milk.  I added a bit of extra Parmesan and a dash of nutmeg to really set the whole thing off.  I served this tossed with linguini and steamed broccoli, and accompanied with homemade focaccia (also from this site).  One last recommendation for folks who say their sauces are grainy- make sure you use freshly grated Parmesan straight from the block.  Don't use the shredded or grated stuff in the tub or the green can.  It is dehydrated and will not melt properly.  That stuff is best used on top of the finished dish or on pizza.  Invest in the real deal and a Microplane grater for this sauce and for most other dishes and you'll never go wrong!  And if you really want to jazz this up, go for Parmigano Reggiano or even Peccorino or Asiago.  That would probably be delicious!

text:
Wonderful!  A few tips: for the best flavor, use unsalted butter and a crushed clove of garlic, instead of the powdered variety.  Also, I used skim milk, lower fat cream cheese, and only about 3 oz. parmesan, and it was still superb, but much lower in calories.  

I did not use a non-stick pan, and had no problems.  

After incorporating the milk, I didn't cook it over a few minutes or so.  It was thin, but thickened up nicely as it sat.  I used this sauce instead of tomato sauce when making lasagna, and it was fantastic!

userID:
5846177
Display Name:
Hattie Alexandropoulos Main
isPro:
False
followersCount:
5
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
7
favoritesCount:
315
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4418422.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a really great quick and easy recipe. I made a couple changes: First, I use fresh minced garlic - 1-2 cloves according to taste. I don't like the garlic flavor of some of the powders and many of them tend to have salt in them. Saute the garlic in the hot butter for a few minutes before you add the cream cheese.  

Second, I cut the amount of parmesan to only 3-4 oz because I add white cheddar to the sauce. Usually around 3-4 oz, depending on how thick I want the sauce and how much of the white cheddar flavor I want. You have to wait until the milk is good and hot - it's got to be steaming before you add the white cheddar otherwise it doesn't seem to melt well. And make sure you wisk! The reason I use white cheddar is because I think it cuts down on the parmesan taste and adds more texture to the sauce. It's got almost a gritty texture - but not clumpy. It's hard to explain. I had a white cheddar alfredo sauce at a restaurant once which gave me the idea to try it. 

Finally, I do use the ground black pepper, but like other people I also add just a touch of nutmeg. It doesn't hurt to sprinkle a bit of chopped fresh parsley on each plate right before serving, either!

text:
It's obviously not the best alfredo that ever existed but it's quick and easy. I joined just to leave this review. I read through and I tend to read the worst reviews first and I thought I'd still try it out after so many bad reviews. I made VERY little because I didn't want to waste. I melted the butter, whisked in a little cream cheese, added in milk CONSTANTLY WHISKING and it came together just fine. Added in the cheese and spices and it was fine. I kept adding milk until I got the desired consistency and even added a few broccoli florets for flavor. It was fine. I didn't measure a thing and it was FINE. I don't see how so many people are having trouble. The cream cheese is not overpowering and it WILL blend if you whisk constantly. I think a lot of people just can't cook because this was ridiculously simple and tasted just fine.

text:
It's... edible. I used fresh garlic, rather than garlic powder and added a little dried minced onion; other than those changes, I followed the recipe exactly. To begin, it tastes nothing like a traditional alfredo sauce. I love cream cheese so I wasn't concerned about some of the reviews that said that flavor was strong -they were right. The cream cheese lends richness but it overpowers the other ingredients and creates an odd taste. I served the sauce with leftover chopped pork and whole wheat pasta. It wasn't bad, hence the two stars, but I wasn't rushing back for seconds. It's a decent basic white cream sauce that's easy to put together but be prepared to make adjustments. It needs something to make the flavors blend. As it is now, it tastes as if something is missing. If I make it again, I'll play with the seasonings. It's a good starting point for a creamy sauce but in no way is it comparable to alfredo.

I thought this was very impressive for a "quick & easy". If you find you want to jazz it up and offset the cream cheese overtones I suggest you saute an onion and a julienned red pepper in the butter (which you can cut in half since the veggies contribute their moisture)first and then follow the rest of recipe as directed. The result was subtler flavors and pretty darn polished for a quickie! Also if you want to maintain the integrity of this as a 'white' sauce use white pepper :)

This was one of the most amazing recipes that I have used from All Recipes!  I doubled the recipe as I was using it for Portabella Mushroom Raviolis that I recently purchased from a school Market Day event.  I was almost sorry I had purchased them because I never have made a sauce I was totally happy with because they tend to seperate and the jar sauces taste rather gross considering the premium price that stores charge for them!  This sauce really complimented the ravioli perfectly!  As another poster noted, the sauce makes a lot.  I made a mistake of making 2 batches, but given the fact I have 3 teenagers that eat everything in sight, I thought it would be a good idea to double it.  I will not make that mistake again....one would have been plenty!  This sauce tastes better than any of the jarred sauces on the market and best of all it really is easy to make....I highly recommend it!

text:
Raves from the family!  Definitely a keeper.  I halved the recipe, except sauteed 1 teaspoon minced garlic in the 4 tablespoons butter, then whisked in the 4 oz cream cheese to that, then stirred in 2/3 cup 2 % milk in several batches, continuing to whisk frequently, then even less cheese--2 ounces (used shredded parmigiano reggiano from Costco), healthy dose of sea salt and pepper and the several dashes of nutmeg as others suggested.  Then threw in 6 ounces cooked shredded rotisserie chicken breast I got at Harris Teeter, let it all cook together a few minutes while my pasta cooked (6 oz dry), then tossed it all together, adding in 3 cups of steamed broccoli.  This dish all together with the pasta, chicken, sauce and broccoli made 4 hearty servings.  Calories per serving calculated on www.myfitnesspal.com:  412.    Extremely filling and everyone thought the sauce was excellent.

This was very good. I was under the impression it may taste too much like cream cheese, but it didn't. I used light cream cheese and skim milk. I added 1/2 cup heavy cream as I had some open. I added this to only 1 cup milk. This makes more than 4 people could eat. I was happy there was leftovers, but it definitely serves more than 4. I added chopped broccoli the last few minutes it cooked. I subbed garlic salt for half of the garlic powder as I was using unsalted butter.  Glad I did as I feel it might have tasted a little bland otherwise. Definitely will make again.

text:
Quick and easy! I used shredded parmesan cheese instead of grated, and minced (jarred) garlic -- yum! The parmesan cheese was a little goopy at first, but after whisking a little more it incorporated nicely. I added a dash of nutmeg and a dash of italian seasoning and that really made it flavorful. I served this over garden vegetable pasta (12 oz box) and it was way too much sauce. Probably about right for 16-20 oz. of dried pasta instead.

text:
We all thought this was a delicious alfredo sauce. The cream cheese makes it so rich and creamy but you really don't taste it.  I used a little less milk, minced garlic instead of garlic powder, and added about 1/4 tsp of nutmeg right at the end.  I didn't mix any herbs into the actual sauce, but you could definitely sprinkle some FRESH oregano or parsley over the top of your pasta dish...even basil would be quite nice. Awesome!

userID:
7384731
Display Name:
CarolLynne

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677173.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is wonderful!  I change it up for what I need.  I use cheddar when I want Mac and Cheese (and it doesn't have that flour taste in it).  I have used this sauce for Fettuccine Alfredo, on pizza and for chicken alfredo lasagna.  I have added a few cubes of chicken bouillon also.  I use this in casseroles too. I saute a tbsp or so of fresh garlic with a teaspoon or so of butter in the microwave and then dice up the cream cheese and soften it there. This is so my younger kids can help me with it.  Then the older kids take over and we transfer it to a saucepan and the stove and add 1c milk and 1c water in place of the milk to cut down on the fat.  To us, it tastes the same.  Sometimes, we use 1 1/2 cup milk with 1/2 c water.  Depends on our mood. This recipe is great as written, but also it leaves room to change up for many more uses.  Tomorrow we are trying calzones with this sauce in them, with broccoli and chicken and maybe ham.  Another use is laying refrigerated crescent rolls in a wreath like shape on a cookie sheet.  lay chicken, sauce, small cut up broccoli, and cheese, and a little bit of this sauce.  wrap ends around this to make it look like a wreath. Top with a little cheese.  Bake in oven per instructions on tube. Sometimes, we put a little of this sauce over it when serving. This is a great recipe to make extra of one day and then you have a second different kind of meal for later in the week. We LOVE this recipe!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/843945.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Let me start by saying that I’m not an Alfredo connoisseur or aficionado. I needed an Alfredo sauce for a baked tortellini with asparagus and broccoli recipe that I made up to use the veggies. I read quite a few of the reviews, especially the lower ratings and most helpful. I cut the butter to five tablespoons; used the Parm in the green shaker jar (gasp); and added a sprinkle of oregano and cayenne. We thought the sauce was excellent. Rich and flavorful and no taste of cream cheese at all; consistency was good: thick enough to cling but not too thick, or too runny. I actually think I could use even less butter next time. I did think it was a bit salty but assume that was because of the cheese. I would definitely use this recipe again! It may be quick and easy compared to others, but to heat and whisk the cream cheese, milk, and Parm, a bit at a time, does take some time and attention. Not sure how that compares to Alfredo that’s NOT quick and easy!

text:
Awesome recipe! Reliable and easy. I scaled it down for only one serving (myself), and based off that I used 1/2 TB less butter; however I used the exact amounts of the other ingredients.  I also used fresh garlic instead of powder, added 1/2 slice of provolone cheese, and a dash of nutmeg.  I wouldn't recommend adding the provolone like I did unless you like very hearty alfredo sauce; it was creamy-overload for me, in my opinion.  The smoky provolone coupled with the nutmeg gave the sauce a warm, rich, and savory flavor.  I had this over noodles with a breaded chicken breast and some roasted zucchini and tomatoes on the side.

A very good recipe BUT - I think it should be noted that grated Parmesan is very hard to melt! Make sure that the milk is HOT when added - otherwise, you'll just have strands of Parmesan in your sauce.

text:
This sauce is AMAZING! I have looked for years to find an at-home sauce that is worthwhile, and let me tell you, this is IT! I know this is "quick and easy" but if you have the time try this: Roast a bulb of garlic beforehand and incorporate it (whole is fine)-wow. I had one leftover from the other night and after adding it, well, it rocked my and the fiance's socks off! I also used the other suggestions and added fresh garlic to the melted butter instead of powdered. I served this over pasta with oven roasted tomatoes, rosemary and garlic (400 degrees for approx. 1 hour). Delish!  Definitely a keeper!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My wife and I love an Italian restaurant in the Chicagoland area called Maggiano's because their alfredo sauce is amazing.   This recipe yielded similar results.   I used Neufchatel cheese from Aldi, two cloves of garlic, 1 cup of heavy cream (as a substitute for one of the cups of milk), Kraft parmesan, a dash of nutmeg, basil and oregano. Absolultely delicious!!!!!   I made it for my wife because I just felt like cooking for her and she was moaning all the way through the meal.   If anyone has problems with the consistency because of the cheese; I took the advice of another reviewer and added it right after the butter and Neufchatel.  Whisking continously is a must.  I also let the milk and heavy cream come to room temperature and added them little-by-little, whisking all the while. Thank you Dawn Carter for this wonderful recipe and all of you reviewers who make such insightful suggestions!

Display Name:
Erika

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This makes a very yummy sauce.  After reading some of the comments, I decided to make a half recipe for my family of four and there was still sauce leftover.  I was also rather intimidated by the fat content so I used skim milk (I would have used lowfat cream cheese, too, but all I had was regular).  The skim milk made it a little runny, so I added in a mix of 1 tbsp cornstarch and 1 tbsp milk and that thickened it up just fine.  I also used fresh crushed garlic instead of powder (although I forgot to cut the garlic in half as I did the recipe so it came out rather strong on the garlic flavor).  I really like that this recipe uses cream cheese to add creaminess and richness instead of a ton of cream and butter.  I also added a dash of nutmeg (which I always use in white sauces) and a dash of italian seasoning.  I added in some shrimp at the very end and served over the spinach noodles from this site.  Very yummy indeed!  I'll definitely make this recipe (or my own variation with little tweaks here and there) on a regular basis.

text:
LOVE IT!  This is something I make weekly at our house, it is in our top 5 favorites for sure!  We have tried lots of variations depending on what we have on hand.  It's really yummy to use fresh garlic and saute it in a little butter before adding everything else, mmmm.  We use skim milk and lower fat cream cheese.  We've tried margarine...yuck.  Fresh parmesian is better than not, but it doesn't make a HUGE difference, there is a difference though.  We love adding chicken and broccoli and serving over noodles.  The broccoli soaks up the sauce like a sponge, it is mouth watering.  Definitely a favorite at our house!  PS: Keep the heat down on the cream cheese and butter until it gets nice and "whippy."  Sometimes I get in a hurry and turn up the heat to high and it gets a little wild.

Oh. MY. GOSH!  This recipe is so good that I'm not even done eating it yet, and I had to come review.  This is good.  There is nothing else to say.  This recipe is delicious.  I made the recipe as is, I just changed the order.  I put the garlic powder and the butter in the sauce pan to melt down.  I also added in some oregano and parsley.  I added in the parmesan next, letting it melt into the butter to make a nice cream.  Then added the cream cheese to melt into the above.  I did all this over low heat.  When I started to whisk in the milk, I increased the heat to the medium.  To the people who couldn't get it to thicken - it probably needed more heat.  It came out delicious.  I ate it over angel hair pasta with some precooked turkey meatballs.  So yum that I can't even fully convey.  I so want to eat more, but my waistline won't appreciate it later.

text:
The VERDICT is in...this is my absolute favorite recipe on AR (so far)!!! So freaking creamy and delicious!!! I used 1 can of Carnation Milk and about 8 ounces of shredded parmesan cheese. The key is to whisk, whisk, whisk on a medium to low setting before adding the milk and use quality ingredients (this is not the time to skimp). Be sure to add the milk little at a time as the recipe states this will ensure a lump-free sauce. At the end I added some nutmeg as others suggested. Also I added steamed broccoli and sautéed shrimp. My hunny thought this was better than any Italian restaurant and kept saying....ouuu that was soo good when are you making it again!?!

text:
I am only reviewing this recipe because I actually followed it exactly... Measuring spoons out and all! The taste was very rich, but wonderful. Like something you would eat in a restaurant. I mixed in chicken I had sauteed in olive oil and seasoned with salt, pepper, and garlic powder, and penne pasta. Garlic toast to "sop" up all the sauce at the bottom was essential!! 
The only ONE thing I would say about this recipe.. it is DEFINATELY more than 4 servings!! More like 6 to 8, depending on what you mix in. One full (14.5 oz) box of pasta and 2 chicken breasts were a perfect proportion, and unless you have 4 large, hungry men, it is more than 4 =)
Thanks for this awesome recipe! Now I can make alfredo sauce without it taking all day!

country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe. Very tasty and smooth. It has become a staple in our household. I did make some changes to cut the fat down a little. I omitted the butter and instead added 1/4 cup of flour to the milk for thickening and heated it up before adding the cheeses. It comes out just as rich and velvety without the fat from the butter. I also used skim milk and low fat cream cheese. I added fresh garlic instead of powder for more garlic taste. It is a really wonderful sauce that I make once a week at least!

text:
I was amazed at how much this tasted like "the real stuff." I eyeballed the ingredients though, when melting the butter and cream cheese together I didn't bother measureing the milk since most previous reviews said that it thickens fast, and it does. I always use more parmesean and garlic than suggested, heehee, and I used low fat cream cheese, you can't tell the difference. My only real complaint is that it will not heat up and be creamy again, leftovers aren't happening with this sauce, that just means you have an excuse to gobble it all up at once.

text:
While I really enjoyed this recipe, easy to make, tastes great, I did find that if you plan to add other ingredients, ie, Shrimp, chicken, vegetables, the sauce does "break down" and becomes very watery and will not thicken.  In the future, I will make the sauce, then serve with the meat & vegetables separately to combine all at the table with the noodles.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Its a good sauce.  Its quick, easy and to the point.  I scaled it for one and it was fine.  I found it needed a lot of pepper.  I kind of thought it was "missing something" but that's just personal taste.   Anyway it isn't grainy if you use fresh parmesan cheese.  Also here are some lump tips.  First, remember to let the cream cheese melt down completely.  Secondly, always use a wire whisk for this.  Third, add the milk slowly and you'll find it comes together nicely.  Just a nice slow drizzle will do.  Also for those with thickening problems I found my sauce to be a little thin too so I let it sit for a minute and it thickened right up.   Four stars for a quick, easy, tastey alfredo sauce!

text:
I really loved this.  I had my doubts but the sauce turned out great and was an improvement over traditional alfredo sauces because the consistency stayed smooth and creamy even as it cooled.  I did make one change and used one cup of half-and-half and one cup of milk.  The recipe says that it makes four servings but it seems to make at least six.  I'm going to use the left over sauce on some steamed veggies tomorrow for dinner.  This is definately a five star recipe!!

text:
Awesome recipe, my picky husbands favorite! Parm cheese is difficult to melt so I start the sauce an hour before dinner and let it simmer on low at the end while stirring occasionally so it gets nice and creamy. I also use half & half instead of milk, because if you are going to eat alfredo, you should really eat alfredo. I also double the pepper... This is not the recipe for you if you are on a diet! ;) Serve with pasta, broccoli, and chicken and BOOM, better than Olive Garden!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674146.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a variation of the Alfredo recipe I found in a light Italian cookbook years ago. 4 stars as is. To make it 5 stars for our family, I saute minced garlic in 1-2 tbs olive oil-not butter. I do use low fat cream cheese and use 2% milk (whatever you have works) and start with one cup. As it thickens, I use white wine to get it to my desired consistency. Then I add a dash or two of nutmeg and a sliver of butter at the end to make it glossy. Use good Parmesan! I have also used a Parmesan/Romano combo.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is absolutely my favorite Alfredo recipe! Admittedly, I was VERY surprised to find that Italian seasoning staples such as oregano, thyme, and tarragon leaves didn't make their way into the recipe. I usually add those and season to taste, along with mushrooms and shrimp sauteed in butter, olive oil, and one clove minced garlic. But, generally, this is a great base. The Parmesan can be overwhelming if it's not really your thing. If it isn't, I would only add the cheese one ounce at a time to your particular tastes. I, however, really enjoy that taste. It's such a wonderful recipe. My family adores it!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed the recipe but did add nutmeg, oregano and some parsley.  I couldn't believe how easy it was and although not exactly like real Alfredo sauce, it is very good and most people have these ingredients on hand.  Once the milk is added the sauce turns creamy and will not be lumpy.  Use a whisk and keep stirring and adding a little milk at a time until it's the consistency you want.  I served it over some baked chicken pieces and spinach fettuccine.  I did not think the cream cheese overpowered the sauce at all. 
Something I don't understand is the people leaving negative reviews saying this is nothing like real Alfredo sauce.  If you're such a connoisseur why would you even try this recipe in the first place?

text:
I have nothing but good things to say about this recipe. I had always made alfredo from a box becus I didn't know how to make a good sauce. There are so many variations and I am extremely picky - this recipe is WORTH trying out. It is VERY rich, I might add, so I may use half cream cheese and half the Parmesan cheese and try a tbsp or two of flour. I would also love to try this recipe with feta cheese. But if I were to make this recipe for someone trying it for the first time I would def keep everything the same becus when I took the first bite I couldn't put it down. Only downside is possible stomach ache if you eat too fast like I did!

text:
At first I freaked out!  I was making a large quantity of this for a buffet but had never made it before(all the recipes at allrecipes I've tried always turn out great!).  I couldn't get the butter and cream cheese to blend.  Finally after the cream cheese was all melted I started adding in the milk  and THEN everything finally combined!  Great receipe, got awesome reviews.  I think I will try to use reduced calorie milk, cream cheese and possible a substitute for the butter to see if I can lighten it up. I also used crushed garlic that I sauted with the butter, gave it a great flavor.

AWESOME! just when you think its not going to work it all comes together.  My advice would be to melt the butter then add the cream cheese and let it melt down a little bit before slowly whisking it into the butter.  I cooked cubed chicken breast seasoned with onion powder and fresh garlic. browned the chicken, and steamed some broccoli and everyone assembled their own plate (I love it with broccoli, the boys won't touch the green stuff).  This is good enough to serve guest and super easy. By the way, I use skim milk and its still creamy and delicious. Thanks for sharing!

text:
Quick, easy recipe. The only problem I had was using 2 cups of milk, the sauce turned out a little runny, though I'm typing this right after I made it. I'm seeing that as it cools down it's starting to have much more of an Alfredo consistency. I'm curious to see how the sauce will set in the fridge. Sometimes food is best the 2nd day! This recipe is more than enough for a 1 lb bag of spaghetti. Added a few dashes or oregano and it seemed to really add the "Italian" flavor to it. Awesome recipe! Great for those who have limited time on their hands

text:
I don't cook.  At all.  Never really have.  But I had leftover chicken and was desperate to find something my picky teenage daughter would eat.  She recently had surgery and all the meds have really been bothering her stomach and decreasing her appetite.  I  used some light cream cheese in the tub I had in the frig, 1/4 cup butter, 1/4 cup margarine, frozen fresh minced garlic cube and skim milk.  Took others' advice and added more pepper and some oregano (didn't have nutmeg, will definitely get some now).  Also took the advice of adding the parmesan (used shredded paremesan in the tub) before the milk.  Also threw some frozen petite broccoli in with my whole wheat fettucini halfway through.  Not only did my daughter eat two plates, so did my 11 year old son and husband.  My son asked me to make it again and my daughter didn't argue with him.  Thanks so much for posting this and inspiring me to cook!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is absolutely delicious the way it is. However I tweaked mine. I use 1 cup heavy whipping cream, and 1 cup 1/2 and 1/2. I use REAL butter not margarine. In addition to the Parmesan Cheese, i also use 4 ounces of Mozzerella. I love CHEESE! I didn't use the pepper. 

Now with this recipe, I made my own person "Zuppa Toscana" Soup from Olive garden. I used half of this recipe for the alfredo sauce, then I poured the other half into my soup which is: 2 quarts of chicken broth and 2 quarts of water that boiled  6 medium sliced potatoes until tender. As the potatoes are boiled, I cooked a full pound of Jimmy Deans Hot Tube Sausage, and drained the grease. Once the potatoes were tender I added the sausage and the alfredo sauce that I made to my chicken broth with potatoes. Let it simmer for about 20 minutes on low, and stirring occasionally so the cheese from the alfredo sauce doesnt scorch in the soup on the bottom. 

Ready to eat with bread sticks! BETTER THAN OLIVE GARDEN's soup or Alfredo Sauce! 

This recipe made two totally great different meals!

None
text:
Thank you Dawn for this simple and tasty recipe. By itself with no changes made I give this recipe a solid 4 out of 5. With these easy changes I give it a 5+++! First and foremost do NOT use a wire whisk in your non-stick cookware. Generally this will chip the coating and can then turn your pot into a health hazard. I always use a metal pan on low heat and never have any issues with scorching. I add a handful of fresh minced Italian parsley, minced garlic and basil. I add this to my butter and saute it a bit then add the cream cheese and between 7-8 ounces of Parmesan Romano Cheese and if possible use half cream and half milk. It makes a lot and tastes even better the second day :)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this last night and it was definitely quicker and easier than my usual recipe....and oh so delicious!  I did 'steal' a few ingredients from my old one to spice this one up a bit such as 1/4 cup of olive oil added to 1/4 cup of butter to cut down on some of the fat.  I also used a 1/4 cup of white wine, 1/4 cup of half and half milk and 3/4 cup of whole milk.  Instead of garlic powder I used minced garlic.  Along with the grated Parmesan cheese (yes, in the green can), I used a handful of shredded Kraft Mexican Four Cheese Blend.  Spices/herbs thrown in (just a dash) were ground red pepper, nutmeg, oregano, parsley, and basil.  We didn't taste the cream cheese either.  I know I changed the recipe quite a bit, but I've been making the same Alfredo sauce for a few years now and I know what we like.  Adding these other ingredients to this recipe made it taste like the sauce we have come to love....it was just quicker and easier for me to make.  Thanks for sharing the secret of cream cheese.

text:
I like this recipe, but I totally used it as a base recipe and changed it! Sorry, but we like flavor. I fried about 8 chicken strips in olive oil to golden brown, sauteed 2 large onions, with 3 chopped elephant garlic cloves. I then melted 2 boxes of cream cheese, and added a nice handful of parm cheese, and 1.5 cups of milk and a large can of diced tomatos. I salted and peppered, and added large amounts of chopped fresh flat leaf parsley. I love tomatos with cream cheese, they really love each other, so I sort of turned this recipe into an alopra sauce...

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Err...This sauce was amazing.  My husband wanted to lick the pan!  We made a couple of revisions, based upon what we had on hand. I used grated cotija cheese, instead of parmesan.  It is the same consistency, but with a mexican flare.  Could not taste the spice in the sauce.   Also used half and half instead of milk.  I was a bit worried that the butter and cream cheese would not incorporate, but adding the half and half a bit at a time helped to quicken that process. The sauce was very good, but doesn't look as appetizing as I'd like. (It's very "white") Next time, I'll try adding some parsley or some other fresh herb to make it more pleasing to eye.  Sauce thickens nicely after being removed from heat.  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
This was a really good recipe! I made one small change, and that was putting one clove of minced garlic in the sauce instead of garlic powder (I love fresh garlic!).  I also put in the Parmesan cheese after the cream cheese melted like one comment suggested. The sauce tasted cheesy and it was very good. My s.o. really liked the flavor and said ''it didn't taste like garlic!'' He hates canned/jarred Alfredo sauces because they just taste like garlic. 
I thought the butter (i used lactose free margarine) in the sauce was separating but after it cooked for  a bit and i mixed it more it seemed to stay together just fine. It DOES however take MORE than 10 minutes to make, I thought. (but maybe that is because I was cooking everything else at the same time).

This was quite good, not to mention super easy, and went together quickly.   I made mine early in the afternoon and refrigerated it until reheating. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I thought that this was great for what it's intended to be:  a QUICK and EASY alfredo!  Is it gourmet?  No.  But it is good, quick and easy.  I have to admit to being worried (and a bit skeptical) when I was whisking the butter and cream cheese together.  It was kind of....broken looking, wouldn't incorporate, and I didn't think it would come together in the end.  I kept whisking away though and as I began adding the milk, it did start to come together.  Because I didn't want the sauce to thicken too quickly, I removed it from the heat and then whisked in the parmesan.  I followed the recipe as written and will use this again.  The only addition that I would make would be salt.  Perhaps 1/2 tsp., depending on your tastes?

text:
Excellent! Never used cream cheese in Alfredo sauce before, but since I had only milk (no cream), I gave it a try. I used fresh crushed garlic instead of powder, so I sauteed it in the butter before adding the cream cheese. I followed another member's suggestion of stirring in the Parmesan cheese before the milk with good results - no lumps or curling. Added a dash of nutmeg - this is such a subtle but  key ingredient in Alfredo sauce.

Display Name:
Tim Kline

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/109081.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First let me say that with a simple recpie like this out on the web, it's a surprise that most restaurants I get alfredo pasta from are unable to really deliver on the flavor.  This recipe does just that!  It was full of flavor and was so simple to make.  A couple of things I will do differently the next time I make it though: 1) I will probably make it thinner while on the stove (by using more milk for desired consitency).  What I didn't think about was the fact that after I poured it over the pasta and chicken it would continue to thicken quite a bit.  By the end of the dish it was a little thick and dry but the flavor was still there.  #2) I will probably start this fairly later than the pasta and chicken.  This recipe was so easy that it barely took me 10 minutes.  Leave this piece for last when making pasta and/or chicken.  Other than that, it was delicious.  I am happy to say I can make my own homemade alfredo sauce now.  I probably will not order alfredo when I go out to eat anymore because it is rarely ever this delicious.  Another good find on Allrecipes.  Thanks Dawn.

I've made this recipe several times. The first time I made this recipe with the exact instructions and found it a little bland for my family's taste. I definately found that adding nutmeg was helpful and a bit more pepper. I increased the garlic and one time used fresh garlic for truly enhanced flavor. Overall, this is a fantastic recipe. I can even put all the ingredients in my Vitamix blender and whip it up until contents are hot and creamy; no stove or microwave needed. Truly a time-saving recipe that can be adjusted to personal tastes quite effortlessly. Bravo for the submission.

text:
I give it 5 stars because it is a great base recipe, i used fresh minced garlic wich i added right after the butter melted and let it release the aromas, then added the c/chesse and only used about a cup of milk first, added a bit at a time more untill the thiknes i wanted (wich ended up to about 1 1/4 cup) seasoned it with powder chiken bullion(maggy, about a tbsp. kosher salt and pepper)and did not add the parmesan (i used fresh shreded). instead i dished my noodles, pour the sauce over toped it with a sauted fresh mushrooms and baby spinach(fresh)mix and than sprinkled with the shreded chesse. this will make my "easy middle of the week meal" options, everyone liked it a lot.

None
text:
This is a great recipe for quick Alfredo sauce.  The flavor and texture are really nice!  After trying the recipe as is (because you really can't rate a recipe unless you're rating it as written) I've subbed 1/2 the butter for olive oil, used reduced fat cream cheese and skim milk with equally tasty results.  The key for this sauce is the garlic to avoid it tasting like cream cheese.  The combination is wonderful.  I like to use chopped fresh garlic in this dish, sauteed in the butter/olive oil before adding the rest of the ingredients.  Finish it off with some chopped parsley or basil and the sauce is excellent with grilled chicken and roasted red peppers over pasta!

text:
10 / 14 / 2008: My very first ever meal, made from AR--and it was EXCELLENT!! I tweaked and used heavy cream instead of milk. First time--and I got the Olive Garden recipe right...and became the family hero!!

Same taste second time I finely diced red and green peppers, which worked very well and gave the alfredo a Christmas holiday appearance!!

March 30, 2017: This one still IS my favorite.  Adjust thickness to your liking, between the milk and Parm cheese ( I like a fine mix between powdery Parm and finely shredded Parm ). 

Don't fret if you make it TOO thick: finely dice up some green onions or add generous dash of parsley. Chill till firm--and you got some very tasty Game Day chip dip.

userID:
2169998
Display Name:
McCrearyacres
isPro:

207
favoritesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/478504.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I originally found this recipe in some church cookbook years ago, and have been making it for my family since then. In some other reviews it was mentioned that the cream cheese mixture is grainy-to solve the problem whisk the butter/cream cheese/milk together as it melts. Doing so will insure that it is creamy. Also, in a pinch, this sauce is easy to make in the microwave-put the cream cheese in a bowl and melt it by itself for a bit. Then add the butter and let all melt together. Before adding the milk, whisk together and continue whisking while adding the milk. To keep it from being too runny, add the milk a little at a time until it is at the consistency you prefer.
Review:
Rating:

text:
Ah, cream cheese... I ate a white pizza the other day made by my neighbor's BFF in which she used this sauce. I loved it, so I tried it on a few of my own pizzas. Topped one with Italian sausage crumbles. The other pizza got grilled chicken and blanched broccoli florets. Husband was not crazy about sauce, but he has a cream cheese mental block. I thought it was totally great on the pizzas. The recipe was so easy to make and turned out thick and creamy just like everyone said it would. I used about 2 cups finely shredded Parmigiano Reggiano and it made the sauce more tangy and flavorful. The sauce also needed salt and onion powder, and I didn't use all the milk.

text:
I've made this twice now and the second time I discovered what it needed. The first time I tried adding some basil and oregano - that was delicious and beautifully creamy, but it still tasted a little weak. The second time I added that, some extra parmesan, two more teaspoons garlic powder and a teaspoon of cornstarch - and it did the trick. Fabulous.

My husband dubs this "my specialty".  My family gets SO excited when I make it.  My favorite way to use it is with Turkey Kielbasa (sliced and lightly sauteed), Broccoli and Penne pasta.  
I have been told it's better than restaraunt alfredo!!  The only thing I changed is that I used Heavy Cream.  Hey, if you are going to do it - do it right!!!!  :)  I also concentrate on making sure that my cream cheese and butter are blended REALLY well before I add anything else.  It almost looks like frosting till I'm done.  Then I add the rest. 
EXCELLENT!!!!

text:
This is pretty tasty for how quick & simple it is to make.  I was worried about the separation issues some people had, but I didn't have that problem at all.  Just whisk it continually while melting the butter & cream cheese, and keep right on whisking as you add the milk gradually.  My hubby used to work at Olive Garden for several years as a server, and he agreed the taste is pretty close to their alfredo sauce.  I did find it needed a tiny bit of salt and more pepper, but overall we were happy with the dish. Thanks for sharing!

text:
I will never make alfredo sauce any other way, this is fantastic!
I halved the recipe and only used 1 tbsp of butter and it was enough for 4 servings of tortellini. also used 1 tsp minced fresh garlic and basil.
If it seems to thin wait until you toss with the pasta it thickens with the starch and cooling.
Today, I made with lactose free milk and margarine, still turned out very good. My son was very happy!

text:
This recipe is wonderful it is very simple yet delicious. My family has made this recipe at least a dozen times over the last year.
I highly suggest using unsalted sweet cream butter for this for the best taste.  Also Name brand cream cheese allowed to soften out of the fridge for about an hour before preperation blends the best and is also less likely to seperate when refridgerated. The amount of garlic can be easily changed to yuor taste prefrences, also pull out your pepper mill for this at the table it adds alot more deepth then the canned stuff while heating.

I love this recipe but made a few changes.  I use fresh garlic instead of powder.  I use half the amount of butter it calls for and low fat cream cheese.  I also use skim milk.  I think it tastes better with the lower fat ingredients and less butter, otherwise it is much too rich for me.

This was so easy and had an absolutely FANTASTIC flavor!   I added a little cajun seasoning to mine and omitted the pepper.  I also did not have garlic powder, so I added minced garlic to the melted butter.  I sauteed bay scallops in olive oil, garlic and cajun seasoning, then I transferred them to the sauce and poured it all over pasta!  This is a real keeper!  TRY IT, you will not be dissapointed.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is such an awesome recipe!  I was 100% satisfied.  I was surprised that it called for cream cheese, but decided to go ahead with it since it got such high ratings...I am SO glad I did!  

The first time I used this recipe, I used one cup of heavy cream and one cup of milk, and added maybe one extra ounce or so of cheese.  It turned out really nice, but very rich.  I joked around by calling it "sophisticated macaroni and cheese" because the consistency was very thick and almost clung to the pasta, which is NOT a bad thing if you're in the mood for that!    

The second time I tried it, I used the 2 cups of milk the recipe called for, and it was still stellar.  I have shared this recipe with several friends, and they have had perfect results also.

I quadrupled this recipe for a group of about 14 and it worked great, it simmered as other things finished cooking leaving it thick and rich- ahlthough I do have tons left over since I wanted more than enough, it has done well in the fridge for the past few days and I'm thinking about freezing it as it is holding up so well which is rare for Alfredo sauce... this recipe is as many others have raved- " a keeper" and if yours happens to be runny I sugest letting it cook longer until just right...

text:
This is a good recipe alternative for alfreo sauce that typically requires cream.  I had no problems with the consistency. I used low fat (neufchatel) cream cheese and 2% reduced fat milk.  I didn't bother measuring the milk and just poured as much as needed to get the desired consistency.  I've made this recipe twice... the first time using minced garlic and the second time with garlic powder.  The minced garlic had an overwhelming flavor.  I much preferred the powdered garlic my second time around.  Served with tri-color bow tie pasta and broccoli.  Delicious.

text:
This is a five star recipe for a few reasons:
1. Minutes before I wanted to cook dinner I found this recipe and had all of the ingredients.  It uses cream cheese instead of cream.  I do not use cream often I don't have it on hand typically.  I would be able to make this recipe anytime.
2. It’s so easy to make, anyone could do it. Just make sure you keep on stirring while cooking.
3. It goes with almost anything. I mixed some nice looking pasta with chicken pieces.  Presto - chango! Chicken Pasta Alfredo - Restaurant style.
4. It's Delicious - for anyone from infants to grandparents.  My one year old loved it. Me too!

Have tried a few alfredo recipes and so far, this one has turned out the creamiest.  I used low fat cream cheese and it was still good.  Also, DON'T EVEN THINK about using the canned parmesan.  Fresh only!!!  It may take a lot longer to grate but it's worth it.  This recipe makes enough sauce for one package of alfredo, and it really does thicken up quickly.  Thank for the great recipe!

text:
I read several reviews and decided to try this recipe and spice it up a bit since the biggest complaint was that it was too bland.  I added 1 tsp. coarse sea salt and 1 TBS dried parsley.  I used fresh garlic instead of powder and doubled the pepper.  Mine was not thick enough so I added 1 TBS Wondra flour and it was perfect.  Also, I used lite cream cheese because that's what I had in the frig and 1% milk for the same reason.  It does make ALOT of sauce, too much for 1 lb cooked linguini, and we used it generously on the linguini.  You could easily half the recipe I think.  Good luck, we loved it and will make it again!

text:
I LOVE this sauce!  After I prepared it once as directed, I tried my own little variation: I browned some minced garlic in a TBSP of olive oil with some oregano and italian seasonings while the butter and cream chese were melting.  Then I drained the oil (and set it side for another recipe) and added the browned garlic to the sauce.  I added a little more seasoning (I love italian herbs!) and it was great.  This recipe is so easy, and can easily be added to to suit your own tastes.  Anyone can make this.  My 19 month old son loved this sauce.  It's even great to turn into a blush by adding a little marinara to it.

text:
My husband and I love this alfredo sauce recipe. It is easy and quick. We love a rich sauce so I sometimes substitute the milk with whipping cream. No calorie counting here. It is wonderful. YUM!! May 8, 2003: I have made this sauce a hundred times with no problems and much success...until today when I used lowfat ingredients. I had a terrible time with it, the ingredients (which are the same as when previously made, except I used lowfat cream cheese and milk instead of half & half/cream in combination with milk) did not want to blend and the sauce never did get thick. I ended up adding additional Parmesan cheese and cream cheese...still no luck. Maybe I am used to a thick sauce but using the lowfat items was very disappointing. PS. I used the lower fat products because I am planning on freezing the sauce and was told that sometimes high fat items do not freeze well.

text:
This was excellent. I used fresh garlic rather than powdered. I also didn’t have milk so I used heavy cream mixed with water. I also added some dried basil (from my garden). Grated Parmesan. It makes a lot. Loved it though. Great flavour! Incidentally, I think it might depend on the quality of the parm that you use. (If you think it tasted like cream cheese)  I always buy and grate it myself vs the instant stuff.  It also freezes and thaws well in case you are interested. When I reheat it though, I do it in a pan and not too high a heat or for too long or it will separate.  Either way, a keeper! Thank you!

text:
Easy - yummy - FAST! Oh my...  this is the best. 
Based on a couple of reviews I used 1 tsp. of fresh minced garlic in place of 1 tsp of garlic powder. I increased the parmesan to 1 cup... and I added a little more milk (2 -1/4 cu.) and cooked it down but left it a little runnier to better cover the broccoli . This sauce with penne, sauteed chicken and broccoli florets was the best I've ever tasted. It will be a staple in my home -  THANK YOU!!

text:
Since I found this recipe a few years ago, it has become my go-to Alfredo sauce recipe.  You can't tell there is cream cheese in it at all.  Another reviewer suggested they couldn't eat it at all unless they added (meat veggies and pasta) to it....but I kind of thought that was the point.  I've never eaten just a giant bowl of Alfredo sauce.  Maybe some people do that.  I don't know.

My family's favorite way to have this is over linguini noodles with shrimp and broccoli.  It's a quick and easy pasta meal that is super delicious!

text:
Quick, easy and amazing. I made this sauce in a last minute crunch. I kind of followed the directions and did not have a whisk, but the sauce still came out delicious—a true testiment to how easy this recipe truly is. I added some cottage cheese and garlic flavored Greek yogurt dip because I did not have enough cream cheese. I think it came out healthier and more to my liking than traditional Alfredo sauce which I find too heavy for my taste. But even if I had added all the cream cheese recommended by the recipe I am sure the sauce would have turned out to my liking. Never going back to store bought again!

It helped that a previous reviewer hinted that the secret is patient whisking. Because I added the milk slowly and didn't overheat, this recipe turned out smooth and creamy with no clumps. I made it exactly as directed for a family of 6 (including 4 little girls between 3-10 years old). It served all with some leftovers. And it was a hit. It was so easy & quick! I followed the recipe except used less milk as one reviewer suggested. EXCEPT: I had to make several substitutions simply because I refuse to go to the grocery store. So, I used 4oz feta cheese, 6oz cream cheese and light butter. I added ground turkey to the final product. I also added fresh broccoli because I was raised to always add something green to alfredo cream sauces. This was super easy. I just chopped up the broccoli & tossed it in. The heat from the sauce warms the broccoli just fine & it added a good crunch!

text:
I made this recipe last night, with the assistance of a suggestion made in a previous rater.  It turned out well.  Rather than garlic powder, I will opt for fresh garlic next time.  I enjoyed the cream cheese, as it assisted, in the forming of the base of the recipe.  It's always a tough call as to what temperature to keep in on, after everyone is served.  The burner was turned off, and like cheese does, it solidified again.  Warming it up for lunch in the microwave, a few seconds at a time, seemed to do the trick.  I would choose to make it again.  YUM!

I live alone and try to come up with quick things I can make, often in microwave.  I was thrilled to find I can put these ingredients in my small processer,  (half recipe) except use canned  coconut milk in place of milk.  Two or three frozen meat balls in cup or bowl  with spiraled zucchini, squash and/or spinach, or whatever desired, a little Alfredo sauce and have a delicious, nutritious meal  in three or four seconds in microwave.  Thick, creamy and delish!

I made this last night and I didn't have any problems making it. The cream cheese and butter mixed smoothly. I used fat free half n half and 3 ounces of parmesan  and 3 ounces of Romano cheese. It blended smoothly and looked good but I did not care for it at all. I could taste the cream cheese slightly and to me it didn't taste like Alfredo sauce. I don't think my switches in cheese and milk would change the taste enough to cause me to dislike it, if anything it would have made it taste better to me. After several bites I had to through it away, I just couldn't tolerate the taste.

text:
This couldn't have been easier! I cut it in half, to use on french bread white pizza. I put a sauce pan on med-low, cut the butter and cr.cheese in chunks, let it start to melt and whisked untill it was smooth...it looked pretty lumpy at first, but magically smoothed out after a minute. I added a tsp of Mrs. Dash italian seasoning also. It was great and took less than 5 mins to whip up!!! So rich! I would not hesitate to use low-fat cr. cheese/milk! I AM going to add a dash of nutmeg to the rest to see how that perks it up!

text:
This is an excellent recipe. My 13 year old daughter loves alfredo sauce, but dislikes cream cheese. While I was making this, she stated, "Wow Mom, what are you cooking? It smells so delicious! I placed some on a spoon and had her taste it. Her face lit up with a huge smile and then puts two thumbs up. Then I mentioned the secret ingredient...cream cheese...hehehe. It is true what others stated about not being able to taste it in the sauce. I adjusted the garlic to 1 teaspoon and added salt and a dash of nutmeg. This sauce is so creamy and full of flavor...we love it!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
This recipe changed my cooking experience! I always cooked from packages, frozen dinners, using cream of something soup. I am a baker, through and through. I love baking anything and everything, and am extremely experimental when it comes to baking new things, but never cooking. This recipe is absolutely remarkable. The simplicity is amazing, and it creates something you never thought you'd be able to create out of those ingredients. I love using small pastas like penne, rotini (corkscrews), and bowties (farfalle) for this recipe as I find it absorbs sauce better. I always add chicken, and sometimes broccoli and fresh cherry tomatoes, but it absolutely sublime on it's own for a midnight meal. I'm a cheese girl, if I was asked what food I'd  want for the rest of my life it would be cheese (or this alfredo), and I love adding in some extra mozzarella as it's cooking for some thickness and texture. This pasta sauce has become my life, and if you follow the directions correctly it is extremely simple.

None
text:
I really like this idea.  The cream cheese makes a very yummy sauce that's quick and easy to make.  With all food, there will be some adjustments based on personal taste/preference.  For me, this needed a lot less milk. I used almost half as much as the recipe called for.  I also used a pecorino romano cheese.  The type of cheese you use will make a big difference as to whether or not your sauce tastes like cream cheese.  Mine did not.  It was just rich and creamy with a lovely pecorino romano taste.

country:
None
text:
I have made this  several times, as chicken and broccoli, straight Alfredo, seafood Alfredo with scallops and shrimp, and broccoli Alfredo. Suggestion to all, I use minced garlic and add it to the melted butter and Saute it a couple minutes. Then add my pepper. After adding the cream cheese I bring back up to temp. Then add either grated parmesan cheese or shredded(IMHO combo of both works best). If I am just using straight grated I bring out the immersion blender to help mix the grated parm in. Hope any of this helps.

country:
None
text:
While this tasted good, this was nothing like alfredo sauce. But it's a quick and easy recipe, extremely convenient for a weeknight dinner, with a very short list of ingredients. The key is to cook on low heat and to keep stirring with the whisk constantly. Instead of garlic powder, I sauteed real garlic in the butter. I used half-n-half and shaved Parmesan and that made the sauce thicker. In a pinch, you could use this as a dip for chips if you reduced the milk by 1/2 cup.

text:
"Good Stuff" to quote my husband. My children chowed it down! I did do a few things different but I don't believe I changed the recipe enough not to rate it according to how it is written. I didn't use powdered  garlic but used left over roasted garlic (3 cloves) and I freeze my cream cheese so when I melted the cream cheese and added the cloves I used my emulsifier to cream the mixture. I tried the sauce and it was awesome on its own, but I wanted to use up some left over smoked chicken so I added that and it added a nice layer of flavor. Also, I was concerned when I mixed it with my noodles that it was too thin, but it does thicken up! So don't freak out when you add it to your noodles, give it a little time like the recipe states and it will turn out nicely.

text:
Wow. It's so good, a lot better than I was expecting. I've often seen good reviews of this recipe, but for some reason didn't think I'd love it. But it was great, just as good if not better than the normal cream- butter-parmesan Alfredo that I usually make. Though reviews said it, I was surprised I didn't taste the cream cheese. Maybe a tiny hint of it, but if you didn't know it was in there, you wouldn't guess. I used light cream cheese because that's what I had on hand, and it still made a nice rich sauce. I would definitely make this again.

text:
This sauce was absolutely delicious! We have tried making homemade Alfredo sauce on a handful of occasions but none of them turned out as beautiful and tasty as this recipe. I followed the recipe but also as other reviewers suggested, added some oregano, nutmeg, and thyme to give it a little kick! I made this sauce using the lower end of heat settings on my stove (settings 1-3) in fear that I would overcook it too fast. Doing this also allowed me time to prepare the noodles and chicken that I was serving without having to rush. I will continue to use this recipe and now refuse to buy pre-made sauce!

I have made something similar to this before and couldn't remember the recipe I used before. The reason I rated it so low is this had no flavor. I followed it to a T. I added some salt, Italian herbs, oregano, onion powder, and more pepper. The added flavor helped a lot. It made the sauce go from bland to tasty.

text:
I read all the reviews (well the ones on the main page) and decided I would switch the recipe up a little :) 
I added fresh tomatoes, garlic paste, basil, and Italian seasoning and let that simmer (first) with some olive oil
then I added the butter
then the cream cheese
after that was cooked down I added the milk, but instead of 2 cups of milk I used 1 cup milk and 1 cup chicken broth 
I let that simmer a little and then added shredded mozzarella cheese
I topped it off with some fresh basil, ground black pepper, and a little garlic powder. 

it was delicious!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I think the recipe was good, but could be so much better! First off I traded the garlic power for a few cloves of minced garlic and let it sautee in the melted butter until golden and fragrant. I used 1 1/2 cup skim milk, and a parmesan and mozzarella mix. I added double the pepper and just a pinch of salt. I was skeptical when I added the cream cheese to the butter, it didn't seem to be mixing, but once you add the milk and whisk away it all comes together. It had a great flavor, no cream cheese taste at all! Super smooth and creamy, I put it with linguine, shrimp, mushrooms and a little lemon. If only I had capers! The recipe says it makes 4 servings but I think it could easily be 6-8 depending on serving sizes.

userID:
1553296
Display Name:
Karen Martin
isPro:
False
followersCount:
10

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/190.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had some issues with this and can't tell if it was user error.  First, my sauce never really thickened. The cream cheese and butter mixture didn't look too promising, but when I poured in the milk it immediately smoothed up and looked beautiful. As I poured in more and more milk, it got too soupy and not saucy any more. I wished I would have stopped when it looked right but I wanted to follow the recipe. After that, I didn't know if it was ruined or if I just needed to keep cooking until it thickened, so I stirred and stirred and nothing happened.  I eventually mixed in some flour paste in hopes that it would thicken. I finally gave up and took it off the heat, and it promptly began to separate. It is possible that I overcooked it waiting for it to thicken, but the instructions are too vague to know how long to stir or what to expect to see.

The end product was tasty even though it was a little oily. It was VERY rich!  I think it had too much Parmesan. I served it over sautéed chicken, broccolini, and rigatoni. No one had seconds.  It did have a restaurant quality flavor, but I won't probably make this again, especially not for my kids.

This came out really delicious and like others have said you do not taste the cream cheese. Now, I'm not able to compare it to other homemade alfredo recipes because I just recently went from being a pasta-roni girl to trying to cook stuff from scratch lol, but I can tell you this tasted really good.   
I made two changes: At the advice of other reviewers I threw in a dash of nutmeg; And instead of garlic powder, I minced some garlic fresh and used that. 
I would definitely recommend at least giving this recipe a chance. We will be using it at our house again!

text:
Okay so I have been using this for years and years. Changes I made: I use garlic OR parmesan since they are quite strong together. I have cut the butter almost completely, and sometimes throw in sour cream. Sometimes I use heavy cream instead of milk. My entire family loves this sauce, and we have used variations for so many things! Sauce for white lasagna, casseroles, etc. It's not just a great alfredo, but a wonderful base for other things!

This is the first time making this sauce and  I thought it was a great fast Alfredo sauce, I made a few changes, instead of using plain cream cheese, I used Kraft Philadelphia Herb & Garlic spreadable cream cheese. I also added about 4 clove of minced fresh garlic instead of garlic powder. The main thing to remember when melting the cheese is keep the heat low and slow and it will turn out smooth and creamy.

text:
I prepared this for my roommates and my boyfriend and they couldn't get enough! It saves very well, can be adapted to whatever tastes you prefer. I added oregano, basil, and bay leaves because I'm fond of that particular spice combination but it can adapt to whatever you want to through at it. It's also great with shrimp or chicken. That being said, I added 4 oz of Mozzarella and 4 oz of Parmesan instead of just the latter because it didn't taste cheesy enough for my particular palette. All in all, it's a great base recipe however not one that I would say follow to the letter.

country:
None
text:
This was really great tasting and pretty easy to whip up.  I was a bit short on the cream cheese, probably only had about 6 ounces, but it still tasted great and easily served 4 large portions of chicken with veggies and pasta for a fairly quick pasta alfredo. I had sauteed the chicken and veggies in olive oil and didn't drain it for this dish --it worked nicely with this sauce. I used parmesan already SHREDDED -- the kind in a plastic tub that is pre-packaged --  and that is pricey to buy (almost $5) and the cream cheese is around $1.50, so this sauce is about a $7 undertaking on average. Depending on sales, you could likely buy the alfredo in a jar for cheaper, but it doesn't taste as good as this in my opinion.

text:
I gave this recipe a 3 out of 5 because it made a great soup! BUT it NEVER set up. I follow the recipe at written-- didn't change a single thing, but 20 minutes after I finished cooking it the consistency was reminiscent of creamy broccoli (without the broccoli). However it did taste really awesome- so I added some freshly diced chives and tomato and used the small shells pasta- VOILA- alfredo soup! It was really great for a failed then salvaged recipe....but I will have to try this again one day to see if the recipe failed me (which I find hard to believe due to the wonderful reviews) or if it was just me mucking something up. But even when my alfredo turns out great, I love a fresh tomato garnish! If you haven't before give it a try the cold crisp tomatoes give it a good texture balance!

Display Name:
faithchops

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2899630.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Read the reviews, made the some changes, ended up adding Italian seasonings and a little extra salt by the end, but it was delicious! Tossed it over 1 box of cooked penne and it was the perfect amount of sauce. Topped with extra parm. This was how I made it: 1/2 cup butter with 2 cloves minced garlic heated just under medium till melted, added 8oz cream cheese and "whisked" (stirred around) until it became "smooth" (almost like a cottage cheese consistency... it never actually gets "smooth" at this stage), slowly added 1 3/4 cup almond milk and cream and water mixture (mostly cream) because I didn't have straight milk, whisked till smooth, added 1 cup of grated parm (a little more than 6oz) and stirred till melted, added about 1/8 tsp black pepper, 1 tsp of italian seasonings by the end and about 1/2 tsp of salt. Thickened up nicely even after being tossed with pasta. Nom nom nom nom nom.

text:
I thought this sauce was MUCH more flavorful than the jar stuff I used to buy.  I only used 1 1/2 C of milk per other reviews, and I still thought it was pretty thin on the stovetop.  Since my husband ended up working late that day, however, I finished it off in the oven and it ended up a little dry.  I think it I were to BAKE it again, I'd use all the recommended milk, but will eyeball it if I make it on the stovetop. It was wonderful flavor though; the butter and garlic were melt in my mouth good!

I wanted to make an alfredo sauce because the stuff in the jar is gross. I saw this one and I thought it would be easy to make. I was a little hesitant because I thought the cream cheese would be kind of weird. 

I did make a few changes to make it lighter: I used fat free cream cheese, light butter, and skim milk. I also used fresh garlic instead of powder. 

It was delicious! I am so glad I found this recipe and anytime I need to make Alfredo Sauce this will be the recipe I use. Thanks!

I love this recipe!  I can't even list the number of different ways I use it in addition to  alfredo over pasta.  One of my favorites is in a tuna broccoli alfredo casserole that calls for a jar of store bought sauce.  This is so much better! Sometimes I used fresh minced garlic as others have done and if I'm in a hurry I used powdered, but either way it is delicious.

If you follow the recipe exactly, you will end up with a delicious Alfredo Sauce. But this recipe is perfect for 'tweeking' to your liking too. I often add roasted garlic instead of powdered garlic and I use low fat cream cheese - scrumptious!! I also occasionally add some Italian spices like basil and oregano and sometimes parsley. This is just a super easy, super delicious sauce that you can customize to your family's tastes.
