text:
three stars because although it was ok, it just didnt wow me or my family. I believe this recipe calls for too much cream cheese. I do like the cream cheese but it was just to much. I also added 2 cups heavy cream but it was just too thick, so I added about a 1/2 cup of milk and that helped. Dont skimp on the parmesan because then the sauce would def. taste just like cream cheese. I also added oregano and more pepper and Im glad I did because with out it, it was just to bland. We have left over sauce so Im gonna tweak it again tonight for left overs.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading the reviews I added the milk a little at a time to get to the right consistency.  I found that adding only 1 & 1/3 to 1 & 1/2 c. of milk was the perfect solution.  That way it was not too thin and not too thick, but nicely coated the pasta. That's the only I'm giving it 4 stars - because I had to make the adjustment to the recipe as written.  Great flavor and really easy.  I also put in some fresh grated nutmeg as I like to do that with cream sauces.  I will definitely be making again, with the reduction of milk, in the future!

First time I made this ... put too much parmesean and too little milk. Second time around ...used 1 cup parmesean and 2 1/2 cups milk. We are a garlicky family so added a bit more garlic and herb seasoning and a bit of onion powder. Also added bacon bits while it was on the stove.

Only reason it's a four star is because I tweaked it a bit. But other than that... super fantastic!

text:

This one was extremely easy and only took me about 10 minutes to make it!  It didn't look like it would taste good, but I put it on cheese tortellini and it was amazing!!  The only thing that would make it better is if it were creamy-er.  I highly recommend this recipe.

text:
I had 30 minutes to prepare a meal and a head of broccoli I needed to use up.  After deciding to make pasta topped with broccoli alfredo, I looked up "quick alfredo sauce" and chose this one.  I have to say, it fit the bill perfectly!  I just happened to have all the ingredients on hand and finished the recipe in time for dinner.  The only thing I would change is the consistency of the sauce that I made... It was a bit runny, and I didn't even use all the milk called for in the recipe.  I think if I hadn't been rushed, though, I could have let it cook longer to thicken it.  Also, I used minced garlic instead of garlic powder because I was out of it.  This is a quick and easy recipe, and I will definitely use it again

text:
This is fantastic and super easy. I will never buy jarred alfredo sauce ever again and when I order alfredo at restaurants I find myself wondering why I am paying so much for something I could make just as well at home. I do use pressed garlic instead of powdered. I also mix in the parm with the cream cheese before adding the milk and it does make it smoother. Then just add milk to your desired consistency. An A+ recipe! *** Also tonight I made it and mixed in canned crab meat and it was fantastic on fettucini with some diced tomatoes! Yum!

text:
Made this recipe tonight and it was a huge hit!  No more jarred sauce for us.  I followed the recipe except for omitting the garlic powder and sauteing a tbs of minced garlic with the butter. 
I am so glad I read the reviews because I would have freaked out at the separated mess the cream cheese and butter made, but it smoothed out beautifully once I added the milk.  I also let the sauce simmer on low while I made the pasta.  It ended up a nice thick garlic sauce.  The husband couldn't taste the cream cheese at all!  Oh and I did use Kraft shredded parmesan & romano cheese in the black can.  Very good!!

text:
We really enjoyed this recipe. It wasn't bland at all, like alfredo sauce can sometimes be. I used a clove (or two) of fresh garlic instead of the powder. I used 2% milk because it's all we buy so I did end up having to dissolve a little cornstarch (about a tbsp) in a little milk (just enough to dissolve the cornstarch) and added it. It thickened right up. I also used low fat cream cheese and 6 cheese italian blend. It was yummy! I served grilled chicken over it and added some sweet cherry tomatoes (halved) and summer squash, both of which I had sauted in EVOO until tender. Excellent meal!

country:
None
text:
I first found this recipe in 2003 and made it exactly as the recipe states.  I thought it was great! Easy and very tasty.  I made it again today as is and just as always it is great as is. 
 
If you are having trouble with it being too thin or are having other problems consider the ingredients you used (such as low fat, no fat ingredients or grated Parmesan cheese vs the powdered kind in a bottle, or even margarine instead of butter) these can make a huge difference in your recipe.  Use REAL ingredients and you will be happy with the results, this is obviously not a low cal, low fat recipe nor should it be and is GREAT as is.

Fantastic alfredo sauce!I used two tsp of minced garlic instead of powder and I let the cream cheese soften and ripped it up into chunks. text:
I must say that I did make a few changes to this when it came to the measurements and used freshly minced garlic instead of powder.  My 13 yr old daughter attempted this one time and it just did not work.  A little skeptical to try this again, I did because I had all of the ingredients, but so glad I did... This sauce turned out perfect!  I found that if you cubed the cream cheese and cut the butter into pads, adding all ingredients in the sauce pot and have this on just above low, once they were about 1/2 way melted started whisking until smooth... everything came together wonderfully!  Thank you for sharing!

text:
I read a few poor reviews and was worried, but all for naught.  This was DELICIOUS, exceeds most restaurant quality sauces in my opinion.  I put the sauce over angel hair pasta and added added lemon pepper seasoned chicken and broccoli florets.  I did use a bit less milk, as 2 full cups makes it rather thing.  The dash of oregano & nutmeg really added depth to the sauce like others have suggested.  I will never use another jar of crappy alfredo sauce again with all the preservatives.  This was just superb...will definitely be making again when I can afford to splurge on my diet!

text:
This was very good, although it was less 'creamy' than I was hoping and the parmesan still felt a little grainy, even after thorough cooking. In the pan, the sauce looked very watery. Once it got on the pasta, though, it thickened up much more than I had expected...put more on than you think! I agree with other reviewers, this makes a lot of sauce; half this recipe was comfortably enough for 3 people. Overall satisfying on many levels; easy, inexpensive, quick, and tasty!

Pretty good for an easy alfredo- a few notes however:  1) it makes a ton of sauce! Overall, easy and quick!  Great with shrimp and pasta.

After reading reviews I melted 1/2 cup of butter with a grated large clove of garlic (little kids don't like chunks of garlic) added the cream cheese and melted it down (all on low) added 1 1/3 cup of milk then 4oz Parmesan and pepper.  This was AMAZING and so easy!  Will make this again and again.  I also made blackened chicken to put on top of the pasta and sauce.  YUMMY!  Kids loved this too.

text:
I found this recipe to be very easy to make. I served it over spinach ravioli that was bought at Costco and it tasted delicious!   Some additions/modifications I made: - Substitute Asiago cheese for the Parmesan because I find Parmesan doesn't melt all that well. I actually found Asiago cheese with Rosemary at Trader Joes for a reasonable price  - Add 1/4 cup wine to spruce up the taste  - substitute low-fat cream cheese  - substitute milk for 1/2 & 1/2  - substitute 2 cloves of garlic for garlic salt

text:
I was very excited about making this sauce after so many great reviews.  Adjustments made were to use 1 cup milk, 1 cup half-n-half, added nutmeg and oregano.  Taste was OK.  My son said it tasted like Olive Garden alfredo sauce.  I don't care for Olive Garden but he does so I took it as a compliment.  My only trouble was in melting the parm cheese.  I had to stir and raise heat to 7 in order to heat it up enough to melt.  My whisk had clumps of cheese at the bottom as I stirred.  I gradually poured the sauce over the pasta, and then would go back and stir some more, pour out some, stir some more until it went from lumpy to stringy to smooth.  Flavor was mild and good.  Absolutely nothing wrong with this sauce, but I don't think it's exactly what I'm looking for.  It needs something more, but I don't know what.

text:
Excellent! I will definitely be making again .. especially since my husband and I are low carbing it. I will be low carbing forever since I have had the Duodenal Switch weight loss surgery.  My husband is on board to do Low Carb diet and has already lost 8 lbs! Here are the Changes I made: I DID use the REAL stick BUTTER , not margarine I used Spreadable Whipped Cream Cheese (All I had on hand) I used 1 cup Half & Half and 1 cup milk instead of the two cups of milk (to reduce carbs) To reduce carbs even more I could have used two cups half and half but I didn't want to use up all my half and half that I need in the morning for my coffee LOL. I used the Kraft REAL grated Parmesan cheese that comes in the plastic shaker tube thing. I did not use 6 ounces. I used less .. about 4. When I placed 6 ounces of the cheese on my scale it was a HUGE pile and the smaller amount seemed fine. It takes a long time to melt the real harder pieces of parmesan grated cheese. They take forever to melt .. but patience is KEY.  Because you don't want to boil it or the milks can curdle.  The sauce was SO SCRUMPTIOUS. Smooth. RICH. Too bad I can't have it over pasta LOL since I am watching my carbs right now.  They do make Dreamfields low carb pasta but I am not sure I trust that it is Truly low carb. Ha Ha Doesn't matter.. we serve this on Chicken and vegetables! You can spoon this stuff over lots of things: even over Scrambled eggs with diced up veggies in the scrambled eggs!! Eggs Alfredo LOL

Excellent and resturant quality. Here is what I did differently: I had some extra heavy whipping cream left over from the crab soup I made so I used half milk (skim) and half cream. I also didn't have enough cream cheese, I did have some neufchatel cheese so I used it too. (Again, half cream cheese and the other half nuefchatel.) I also used 2 cloves garlic, not garlic powder. I topped each plate of fettucine with a couple scallops and a splash of parsley and served it. Everyone loved it. Great!!!

text:
Definitely lives up to its title as being quick and easy.  I combined several of the reviewer suggestions and added: 1 tsp oregano, 1 tsp parsley, doubled the black pepper to 1/4 tsp, used a few dashes of nutmeg and used fresh garlic in the butter, but still I think it needs a few dashes of cayenne or more of all those seasonings for zip.  I also sauteed in olive oil in a separate pan: more fresh garlic, chopped onion, 3/4 lb. shrimp, and a cup of coarsely chopped spinach which I stirred into the sauce and pasta.  I used this sauce over 1 lb. of linguine, but using 1 1/2 lbs. pasta would have been a better amount.  Overall the sauce has a bland flavor, but you can add various things to make it more interesting.  Definitely earns points in the quick and easy category, but get creative with add-ins to make it really good.

text:
I have made this several times already and the whole family is crazy about it! I even entered into a cooking contest using it over these great chicken rolls that I found on here, that are more like spinach stuffed chicken, and took 1st place! I use half garlic salt and half garlic powder as we like the flavor and saltiness of it. Since I found this recipe no one wants to eat italian at an restaurant anymore. It is worth it to be slow about getting the ingredients mixed and melted just right as the ending result is sooooo rewarding. And I use my stainless steel pans and they never burn or anything you just have to know how to control the temperature. For those who said this was mediocre and a waste of time, you obviously have missed something or are used to that nasty grocery-store jar sauce. This is just like the sauce from our local Italian hot spot. A-mazing! Thanks so much!

Display Name:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed another reviewer's advice and added tsp minced garlic and reduced milk to 1 1/3 cups and parmesan to 4 oz (good thing - only had 4!). When whisking the cream cheese into the butter I did panic at first. It was VERY lumpy and didn't look like it would smooth out. Even though it said "until smooth" I didn't think it was smooth. The cream cheese just wouldn't incorporate totally with the butter. It almost looked like curdled milk. So I just added the milk anyways a little at a time. The more milk I added, the smoother it became. It wasn't lumpy at all and was quite yummy. The whole family agreed!  Oh and I also added about a Tbsp of dried parsley near the end too - just for a bit more flavor and color.  Definitely recommend and will make again!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It is a bit different than traditional Alfredo sauce...definitely has a slight cream cheesy taste, but wonderfully creamy.  I do not think it any easier than making a traditional roux Alfredo.  I did add a t. minced garlic to the butter (I used real butter), used 1 1/3 c 2% milk, a little less than 1/2 a container of Parmesan cheese (all I had) and S/P.  All these changes were based on the review written by Reg927.  I did also add pumpkin spice because at that very moment I realized we were out of nutmeg!!  I used this Alfredo with the Lasagna Alfredo Roll-Ups (AR).  My family thought the entire dish was wonderful!  Though, my 18 month old didn't have anything to do with the dish.  The whisk is a must!  Do have patience and just when you think the sauce is looking meek, grainy, separating and not coming together nicely...whala!  It'll all come together and be perfect!  Keep over medium heat.  Don't rush it!

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2010-02-15T10:42:00.487
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
4506678
Display Name:
byjillian
isPro:
False
followersCount:
3
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
25
favoritesCount:
87
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5708132.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Bring sauce to a boil, quickly lower the heat and then serve immediately.  My issue was that I could not get the sauce to thicken up all that much, but as soon as I boiled it and then reduced the heat, that did the trick!  Also, if you want to add spinach, I bought the green giant frozen package of 10 oz spinach, cooked in the microwave, squeezed out the juice (use gloves, it'll be hot...), and stirred in with the sauce before bringing it to a boil.  Stick with the recipe when it comes to the milk: 2 cups is plenty, just be sure to have all of your 'before' ingredients nice and smooth (the butter, cream cheese) BEFORE adding the milk, otherwise you will end up with a clumpy mess.  Also, if you want to save any of the sauce, spoon out what you want to eat and then pour the rest into a jar/container right away, otherwise it will be very thick and hard to get out of the pan!  Hope this helped, Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
I give this five stars for flavor (after mod.):***** I give it three stars for directions:***  I used fresh garlic instead of powder.  The flavor was awesome!  It took a very long time for in to thicken.  I think this recipe should call for fresh parmesan, because the Kraft never really "melted" into the mixture. It left for a strange texture, although very tasty.  Next time I will use 1/3 cup butter, 2 1/2 cups milk, FRESH parmesan, of course fresh garlic, and will remember to prepare to cook for quite some time.

text:
Added a medium chopped onion, some sliced mushrooms, and fresh garlic to the butter. Once the onion was translucent, I added the cream cheese, 1 1/2 cups milk, 1/2 cup of half and half, and the parmesan. To make it more of a meal I mixed in a frozen package of spinach (cooked and strained) and about 2 cups of chopped ham that was leftover from Christmas. Tossed in the pasta and we had a delicious one pan dinner!

text:
I have a 6 year old and 12 year old who want to eat at Olive Garden every time we ask where we're going for dinner.  They love this recipe and beg for it weekly.  I had been using a different recipe that called for heavy cream, but found that the cream was not only more expensive, but left a filmy texture when eating it.  We don't notice the separating of the butter as much with this recipe, and I use real butter.  Overall for the ease in cooking, the handiness of the ingredients and the taste, it's definitely one of the top 5 in my recipe collection.

userID:
2882096
Display Name:
Amy Ashburn-Forest
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4349832.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed the recipe for the most part, but followed other reviewers' advice and cut down on the milk.  I only used a cup as I like really thick alfredo sauce.  I also used minced garlic instead of the garlic powder.  I don't generally rate reviews after I alter the recipe, but I have to say that when done right, this sauce was amazingly easy.  You really need to keep whisking and I brought the consistency up before I added the cheese at the end.  I whisked in the cheese until it was melted and used fresh cracked pepper.  It was great stand alone but then I sauteed smoked sausage and roasted red peppers.  I added the sauce and the sausage/peppers to the cooked pasta and mixed well.  It was served to my fiance, a couple of friends, and a picky three year old (I gave her noodles and sauce and had to remove the sausage and peppers from hers).  Everyone loved it.  Personally, I use recipes as a jumping point, but if you are a novice cook, then follow the recipe first and then tweak to your tastes.  I come from an Italian family, so I personally always use fresh garlic, pepper and cheese.  I have "shaky cheese" as my daughter calls it, but I use it as a topper and not a mix in to my recipes.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/134554.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I really did like this, but I did change it to suit how we eat.  To lighten it up, I use only 1/4 cup of butter.  It still comes out rich and creamy, and I feel better about it.  Second, I use half the amount of garlic powder.  The first time I made it, I used all the garlic powder to rave reviews, but it was too strong for me.  I serve this over whole grain penne with sauteed chicken breasts and fresh vegetables like zucchini, summer squash, asparagus, mushrooms-- whatever is on hand and in season.  With delicate fresh vegetables, I want their flavor to stand out. This sauce comes together quickly and easily, and is good with all the garlic or half, but I definitely recommend cutting the butter in half.  The kids have requested to have this more often.  High praise!

After tasting the finished product, I found it too bland so I followed other reviewer suggestions and added nutmeg and oregano, two things I've used in other alfredo recipes and enjoyed. The sauce was too heavy (yes, I know alfredo is a heavy sauce to begin with) and lacked the strong flavor of a traditional alfredo sauce. I think maybe the cream cheese dilutes the parmesan taste. My family could barely finish it (a rare occurrence). The time saved just wasn't worth it. I'll stick to garlic, butter, cream, and parm.

Very quick, easy and tasty.  I wish I would of listened to my instincts though and sauteed some minced garlic in the butter and left out the garlic powder.  I really think it would improve this dish.  Having said that...I used low fat cream cheese, non fat half-n-half, smart balance butter and added sauteed mushrooms, zucchini, some blanched broccoli and the best thing.....some big fat healthy shrimp & mixed it all with some fettucini.  Even with the low fat ingredients this was good. Consider the fresh minced garlic - Next time I'm adding at least 3 cloves.  Thanks Dawn for sharing your recipe.

Display Name:
ABSOLUTBOUCH33
isPro:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/3054.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I can't believe that such an easy recipe could be SO good! I'm a huge Fettuccine Alfredo lover and this sauce is the best I've made. However, I was shocked to find that my fiance, who doesn't really care for Alfredo sauce, thought this was to die for! So it's good enough to please both Alfredo-lovers and non-lovers. I make just a few tiny modifications: I mince a few cloves of garlic and saute with the butter (we are garlic lovers) and cut back on the garlic powder. I also add a few shakes of ground nutmeg at the end; this adds just a little something special (but it doesn't taste "nutmeg-y" so don't worry). I also add a bit of coarse Kosher salt or sea salt and I put the parmesan on the table instead of stirring it into the sauce so everyone can choose how much they want. My final tip: use a wire whisk to mix the cream cheese into the butter (and again when you add the milk). When I do this, it's always 100% lump-free!

text:
Well, I have to say that I am a LOVER of all things cream cheese, and use it as a base for just about any cream/cheese sauce I am making instead of a traditional rue. With that being said, I have NEVER used cream cheese as the base for an Alfredo sauce! I am a traditionalist when it comes to Alfredo, and always went through the painstaking task of making it entirely from scratch. I have to say, though. This is just as good, if not better than most I have made/tried. The best testament to the sauce was a girlfriend of mine who was visiting while I was cooking. I was making homemade fettuccine noodles to go with the sauce. She kept making the comment that she HATED Alfredo sauce. When the meal was ready, she ate her helping, her sons, and I nearly had to arm wrestle her for what was left in the pan! ;) Fantastic sauce! I did take the suggestion of a few posters and added a dash of nutmeg and oregano, along with half heavy cream and half milk, you know if you are going to eat, go all out! The depth and flavor added by these simple changes made it outstanding! I tried it just by the recipe guidelines and it was also really great! I topped the pasta with the sauce and a mixture of marinated chicken breasts, and bacon-SINFUL! This is a meal I will be making again and again! Thank you so much for the posting! Great idea!

text:
If I could rate this a 5+ I would!  I was admittedly a little skeptical about making this with cream cheese but gave it a try anyway.  WOW!  It was excellent.  Better than any Alfredo I have had out of a jar and possibly even in a restaurant!  My two toddlers loved it.  My 4 year old had seconds, which is rare! My husband, who is NOT an Alfredo sauce fan at all, even liked it.  He said he would taste a bite and see if he liked it and then proceeded to heap his plate with a huge serving and ate it all!  You can not tell that this has cream cheese in it at all.  The only things I did change was to change the 2 tsp of garlic salt to 1 tsp garlic salt and 1 tsp minced garlic.  I also added a dash of basil and nutmeg as other reviewers had suggested.  I also tossed in some steamed broccoli.  I can't wait to make this with some grilled chicken.  Thank you for sharing this recipe!  I will never buy Alfredo sauce again!

text:
I made this last night on a whim (I've been meaning to make it for about 2 years). I just so happened to have all of the ingredients in my kitchen. I scaled this down to two servings (which really is about 3 or 4) and used a little less than 1 cup milk, about 3 tbs butter, 3 tsp minced garlic, and a about 3 ounces of cream cheese - I wanted to make as little as possible. It turned out FANTASTIC. In the end I added a LOT of ground black pepper, but that's just how I like my alfredo. I was so surprised at how tasty this recipe was, expecially since the main ingredient was cream cheese! I will defninitely be making this again!

I was very, very, skeptical of an Alfredo recipe that called for cream cheese, but I was also very, very desperate for some fettucine Alfredo. I'm glad I tried this. The flavor was excellent. I used 2% milk, reduced-fat cream cheese, and pre-grated Parmesan from the green can and it was still great. It was cheaper and better than, Alfredo sauce from a jar, and easier than a traditional homemade Alfredo sauce.

I have to give this five stars because I don't like the jar stuff and have never attempted to make it from scratch until now. I read all the reviews (well most) and followed the recipe almost to the tee. I added italian seasoning, fresh ground black pepper, no salt (it didn't need any). EXQUISITE!!! Mahalo for this recipe!!!

text:
OMG so tasty. I gave it 4 stars because I tweaked the recipe a bit. I first melted only 1/4 stick of butter and threw in some fresh chopped garlic. I then added low fat cream cheese until melted. Added only about 1 1/4 cup of 2% milk then seasoned w/ salt, pepper, & a dash of nutmeg. Oh and I also put in about 1/4 cup of shredded aged parmesan cheese.  Served it with pumpkin ravioli's. My hubby and I ate almost the whole thing ourselves!

text:
The title says it all...this recipe was quick and easy and very good I might add :) I used 1/3 less fat Philly cream cheese and organic skim milk.  I served over bow pasta and pesto chicken breast with garlic bread. For those who like to add nutmeg, etc. to their Alfredo, this recipe allows you the flexibility to do so...I chose to follow recipe exactly this time around and was happy with the result.
UPDATE:  I now add a little nutmeg (very little, as a little goes a long way) and it does seem to add some depth to the flavor.  It was great before and now, I think it's even more amazing with the touch of nutmeg.  Hope this helps!

text:
Well after coming back here I must have read too many reviews and changed the original some. I was in a pinch and only had limited ingredients on hand, was hoping this would work. I used heavy whipping cream and a little half and half instead of milk.  I only had canned parmesan and didn't want the sauce to be grainy, so I put it in my blender first.  Added some cream to the blender too so I could get all the parmesan out.(ha ha)  I only used half of the cream cheese cause that was all I had and I microwaved it first to get it soft.  Was hoping it would be easier to blend with the butter and garlic I sauted.  Seemed to work pretty good, I had no problems with it being grainy or oily just a nice sauce.  My husband even put it on his hot dog.  Mind you I don't recommend that, cause I did not try it. Sounded yuck to me, but he assured me it wasn't.  Yes we were really scraping the cupboards today!!

text:
I was making dinner for some friends, but I work until pretty late in the evenings. I made this sauce the night before. I added some nutmeg (after reading the reviews). It was wonderful the night before - it was smooth, velvety, perfect. Last night, however, when I was getting ready to serve it, it seperated a little bit. It still tasted wonderful, but the seperation caused the texture to be a little less than great. I highly recommend making the sauce for the same night it will be served. Oh! I was having 6 people for dinner, so I upped the servings to 6. I ended up with a TON of alfredo. The original recipe would have easily sufficed.

text:
This is very good and oh so easy.  I did have to let it sit for 8-10 minutes after removing from the heat before it thickened up.  Also, make sure all that grated parm melts before you take it off the burner or the sauce will seem a little gritty.  I used the reduced fat cream cheese, 1% milk, and 2 tsp of minced garlic.  Next time, I'll add grilled chicken, shrimp, and some broccoli.  This is a keeper.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is absolutely wonderful! So easy and quick to make. No hassle, no fuss, and very delicious and authentic tasting. You really do not taste the cream cheese in there. For those who had a hard time blending the cream cheese with the butter over the stove, I think it might help to have the cream cheese at room temp before you start. However, it is not such a problem, because everything starts coming together nicely once you start adding the milk and whisking at the same time. I added some leftover cooked chicken pieces and a bit of nutmeg to the sauce, and I also added some mixed frozen veggies to the pasta during the last 3 minutes of cooking. After draining the pasta, I mixed in the sauce. Perfectly complete meal in one single dish! Contains all food groups. Love it! Thanks for sharing the recipe!

city:

country:

text:
I found this recipe on 6/2.  I am a simple type of cook! I don't like alot fuss & definitely not alot of mess! Plus I like things to have fresh & simple taste! I wasn't really sure about the cream cheese, but figured I would give this recipe a try. It was very easy to make,extremely creamy, and tasty!!!  Since I don't use whole milk, I used 1% milk and also fresh garlic.  I think because I used 1% milk, it didn't quite thicken like I wanted  that night. Plus I made the sauce pretty late at night. So I would imagine it would have thickened a bit better had I made the sauce at a more reasonable dinner hour. I probably could have let it thicken a little while on medium heat. But again, it was late & I was hungry! I definitely will use this recipe again!  I may try it with light cream cheese and 1% milk to see how that comes out!
6/26- I made this recipe again and decided to do it with whole milk this time. I was making it for me and my boyfriend at his place. Not sure if it was his stove or what. But when I tried to melt the cream cheese, it really just wouldn't melt.  So intstead of just wasting it, I put the melted butter and 'sort of' melted cream cheese in a blender. Then I added the 2 cups of milk, garlic, a bit of salt and pepper. That all blended very well! Lastly I put that mixture bank on the stove to heat it up and added the parmesan cheese. It thickened really quickly! My boyfriend loved it and said it was extremely creamy! I loved it too! It was even better than the

I would give this a 3.5. My biggest problem was the consistency. It seemed like it was too thin, so I kept on adding more and more parmesan cheese. After the sauce sat awhile, it tasted gritty when we had 2nds. I added grilled chicken and served it over bow-tie pasta. It was good, but it might be easier just to stick with the can variety.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I will admit I was a bit unsure about the cream cheese, but I was impressed. It did turn out a super creamy sauce. I would recommend using a real cheese not imitation (i.e. Parmigiano-Reggiano, what I use, or Grana Padano) because that is the main flavor. Like others, I also used fresh garlic, more pepper and served with chicken over spinach pasta instead of regular for health as well as taste. For me, I thought the recipe made way too much. I had a ton of leftovers (not great for reheating in the microwave, but did ok on the stove—I would also recommend not mixing extra sauce with noodles so you can re-wisk the sauce). Next time I will use 1/4 of the recipe, which should be plenty for 3-4 people. Overall great recipe!!

text:
This is the best, quick alfredo sauce I've ever tried.  I had mixed 4 T. butter, 1 t. Italian Seasoning, 1 t. Parsley, 1 glove of Garlic, and 1/4 t. Black Pepper into my last 8oz. block of cream cheese the night before to put on crackers.  I had most of it left over so, I used that in a pinch!  I left out the Garlic called for in this recipe since the cream cheese already had some in it.  It gave the sauce a GREAT flavor!!  My mother and aunt told me to remember how I had made this because they want it again.  

P.S.  My one year old twins gobbled it up too!! I made theirs with the large size pasta shells.

I only had 1% milk and thought it would be too thin, so, I used part milk and part heavy cream. I also marinated and cooked some chicken and steamed some broccoli that I added to the dish. text:
Update: This works just using the 1/4 cup of butter and also using just milk. I tried to freeze the extra and it wasn't good. Even after only a week. 11/28/07:Totally nummy! I wanted to substitute fat free 1/2 & 1/2 like another reviewer but decided to stick the the exact recipe first. I realized I had accidentally bought Neufachetel (sp?) cream cheese, but it was great. I was afraid it wasn't going to thicken because it was taking a while at first, but it suddenly thickened right up after I stopped stirring and let it heat up every once in a while. Next time I will try the fat free 1/2 & 1/2, and not use quite as much butter, I think it would work just as well with just 1/4 cup. Thanks!

text:
Quick, easy, inexpensive, delicious,  perfect!!!  I added a little more cheese and a bit of fresh grated nutmeg. I made this a few weeks ago and we enjoyed it but there was a lot of sauce leftover.  I intended to make an alfredo chicken pizza but didn't get to that so I put the sauce in a baggie and froze it. I figured I could throw it out now or throw it out later if it didn't hold up to the freeze. It did.  We had the rest last night and it was perfect again.  Thanks, Dawn. Update: Made this easier and healthier last night.  2T butter in sauce pan to melt.  1 1/2 C  2% milk, low fat cream cheese, canned parmesan, pepper, garlic powder and appx. 1/4 t. fresh grated  nutmeg into the blender then poured that into the melted butter. Kiddo never would eat alfredo.  This is now her new favorite.

This is the best "homemade" Alfredo recipe I have tried. It was very quick and creamy. It doesn't taste too much like cream cheese like the other recipes I have tries. This recipe made enough sauce that I refrigerated some and had it over pasta the next day too. 
The only thing that I changed in this recipe was that I used minced garlic instead of garlic powder, and added that when I was melting the butter. The rest I did according to the recipe. Very creamy and yummy!!

CAMCHES

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614252.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It was certainly quick and easy but the recipe looked bland so I doctored it.  I sauteed chopped onion and minced garlic with the butter.  I added a large dash of nutmeg, 1/4tsp of red pepper flakes, a dash of cayenne, italian seasoning, and salt because I used unsalted butter.  I added julienned ham and peas to make a more filling meal.  I only added 1 cup of milk and that still made it a little too thin but I turned up the heat and it thickened.  It was good, but it needed to simmer for a while to let the spices balance out the cream cheese taste.  There is a cream cheese taste, although I imagine if you used one full cup of milk, it'd be less obvious.  The cream cheese taste was unnoticeable with the pasta, though.  I think this would make a good base for another sauce.  It was good but a traditional Alfredo sauce is already so easy.  But for times when I don't have cream, this will be my stand-by.

text:
Congratulations! This is the best and easiest recipe I've ever come across. It's great on it's own or as a base to many pasta recipes. 

The second time I made it, I microwaved 3 cups of frozen broccoli florets in 1/4 cup of water for 5 minutes, strained them, then stirred them into the sauce before mixing it with  rotini. It was wonderful!

 Store bought grated parmesan works just fine. Of course, the higher quality ingredients you use, the better the sauce will taste.

text:
I will never buy jarred alfredo sauce again! The store bought stuff is bland and expensive. This recipe is the complete opposite! Its very cheap and wondeful. It's not like Olive Garden but it definitely works for homemade. I used lite butter, cream cheese, milk and cream and they came out fine. I used 1 c. fat free creamer and 1 c. milk. Also, the butter/cream cheese will blend better once the milk/creamer is added. I also used more parmesan and about 1 1/2 t. garlic powder and a little bit of italian seasoning. Mine wasn't too runny or too thick. I'll definitely add this to our regulars!

text:
This worked ok, though I probably will revert back to a "true" alfredo sauce in the future.  I used 4 cloves fresh minced garlic, rather than garlic powder.  Only used 1c of milk, rather than two; 2c of milk would have made this too thin & runny. Doubled the parmesan.  These changes made a good thickness for this sauce. Because the parmesan wasn't melting well, I ran it through the blender and it came out smooth.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is fabulous!  I have made it many times now, and although its five star as is, I have changed a few things to suit my tastes.  I use 2 tsp of garlic paste because it has better flavor than powder imo, and I add about a tsp of dry basil.  Also sometimes I like to saute chicken and broccoli and add that in at the very end.  Taking about a 1/3 of a lemon and squeezing the juice into the sauce then slicing up the remainder of the lemon into round slices for garnish adds great flavor and an elegant look.  One thing I do recommend is using fresh shredded parmesan rather than Kraft grated or some such.  You can buy it already freshly shredded to save time, its usually near the fresh pastas.  This recipe is not only delicious but its versatile too. Can be kept simple for a side dish or can be combined with veggies and chicken or shrimp for a main meal.  I feel like a gourmet cook when I make this lol.  It's deffinately restaraunt quality.  Thanks so much Dawn for a great recipe!

text:
OMG ... this is absolutely fantastic!  Thank you ever so much for this recipe.  It's too bad I can only give it a 5 star rating, it deserves at least a 10.

The Alfredo Sauce is all made, it's sitting in the pot (what's left of it).  LOL  It's not quite 5:30 p.m. and I have to wait until 6:00 p.m. before I can put on the Gnocchi (potato dumplings) that I'm going to pour this over.

I only made a half a batch as it's only the two of us and I'm serving the gnocci with Alfrdo sauce along with a ham steak. 

I doubled the garlic (the fresh diced garlic in the jar).I grated fresh parmesan but as I was tasting it I grated extra and threw it in.  Then I added some more (this time it was Tre Stella in the jar because I had used up all my fresh parmesan).  I doubled the pepper and used white pepper instead of black.

I sure hope the gnocchi doesn't ruin the taste of this excellent sauce.  LOL

I bought a lot of cream cheese on discount and since this recipe received so many rave reviews I simply must try it. Instead of using garlic powder, I fried it using the melted butter first, then add in the cream cheese, and I substituted evaporated milk instead of the milk. Turned out creamy, rich and lovely. If only my digicam hadn't been loaned out to my mates, would had made a good photoshoot. I also tossed in some dried parsley flakes for a nice touch of colour.

This is fantastic!!!  My husband and I both loved it.  It does make alot so I added cooked broccoli, red peppers, mushrooms, peas, zucchini, onions, and halved cherry tomatoes to a lb. of angel hair and tossed every thing together.  It reheated very well as, without the cream, you don't have to worry about separation.  We lived on it for a couple of days and were as happy as clams.  Another advantage is the ease of proportion so you can make just as much as you need - even for a side dish.  Oh, I also added some fresh garlic.  My mouth is watering just thinking about this recipe.  Excellent!!

text:
I was really skeptical of this recipe.  Nothing this easy can be so good is what I thought.  Boy was I wrong. It is easy to double, or even half, and is our favorite alfredo sauce hands down now.  It goes well with any pasta, or as a cream sauce for chicken breast or fish fillets.  Our favorite way though is shell pasta cooked with broccoli, julienne carrots, peas and cooked chicken bites.  And it does get very thick after it is removed from heat.  I didn't think it would at first.  Like I said, I was pleasantly surprised, and this is definitely a keeper.  Thanks so much for this recipe.

I don't think you can ruin this recipe.  I will probably try this recipe with lemon chicken instead of just plain whipping cream.  Actually, I think a little lemon would be good to this sauce when using as an alfredo!!

text:
I’m not sure what I did wrong but my sauce never thickened so I had to add some flour.  Also we found it to be very bland  I also had to use more Parmesan cheese than called for. The amount of milk may have been to much but I read the reviews and it seemed like 2 cups would be ok. It made a lot of sauce, fed the four of us with a little left over even. It wasn’t a heavy sauce either even though there’s so much butter. I did use real butter as well. With some modifications I brought it up to what we like. I added 2 Tbl of little devil hot sauce, some old bay seasoning, more herbs more pepper and more garlic. While it was cooling I added my Shrimp, they were perfectly cooked.

text:
I made this sauce substituting  2 cloves of garlic instead of the powdered garlic. I also doubled the recipe. Very easy to make! I tossed the sauce with one and a half boxes of cooked penne pasta and 4 sliced up chicken breast. Topped it with a 8 oz bag of Italian blend cheeses, parsley and a sprinkle of Tony Chacheres creole seasoning, baked for 10-12 min, until the cheese was melted. Served it with a side of garlic bread.  My family absolutely loved it! Delicious!!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Honestly think I like this more than making alfredo sauce with heavy cream! The cream cheese just seems to agree with the ingredients more, it combines better with the milk and parmesan, and tastes sooo much richer! My only suggestions for improvement are put a lot of garlic in the butter before adding the cream cheese and let it brown a little, and add some parsley (fresh or dried), adds a wonderful touch! I saw another reviewer say it's a little too much sauce for a pound of pasta and I agree, but the sauce tastes so great that we don't mind at all!

text:
After reading several reviews I made this and also tweeked it a bit. The whole family loved the dish. I made a Cajun Chicken Alfredo Pasta dish. I added the pinch of nutmeg that  others suggested. I also used 1/2 c grated Parmesan and 1/2 c shredded Parmesan. I used 1 tsp garlic powder and 1 tsp minced garlic. We loved it and I will make it exactly the same again. The consistency was perfect.  Can't wait to share it with my daughter who loves Alfredo sauce

text:
Good for a quick pinch and my favorite  recipe. My husband and kids actually prefer jar (and used to complain up a storm when I didn’t  have it on hand) but now they are used to it. 

A few things you need to know. 

-Stop at one cup milk and add more slowly to reach your desired consistency. 
-Real Parmesan cheese melts slowly so be prepared. 
-The lower your milk fat the thinner your result will be so you may need to adjust your cheeses and/or milk amounts.

My daughter and I love Alfredo with pasta or to dip our bread sticks. I just winged it with these ingredients. I used whipoed cream cheese, real butter and milk, kraft cheese because that's what I had on hand. I used garlic salt with parsley and crushed some black pepper over it. I just melted everything by mixing all ingredients slowly. It came out delicious. I highly recommend this for anyone thay enjoys going out for pasta. It's just like the restaurants. Maybe not authentic Italian but I'm not Italian so I wouldn't know. Thank you lord for this deliciousness!

userID:
1519356
Display Name:
Erin Roubicek Slavin
isPro:
False
followersCount:
8
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
27
favoritesCount:
193
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1430223.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the best alfredo is the world!! I have made it for years as is and it's great!  But with a few recent additions, it's superb!! If you have these ingredients, I highly recommend trying this! Add 1 tsp of minced garlic to butter. Then put in cream cheese and whisk until it is totally melted and you can't see any butter.  Add 1 cup whipping cream and 1 cup milk instead of 2 cups milk.  It will be very milky. Add 4 oz grated (in shaker) and 3 oz of shredded parmesan and whisk over low. If you love garlic as we do, add 1/2 tsp fine grnd garlic to sauce. Increase pepper to 1/4 tsp, 1/4 tsp nutmeg and  1/2 TBSP oregano. OMG!! HEAVEN!! Hint: While noodles are cooking, take sauce off the heat. It will thicken beautifully!
Review:
Rating:
5

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
If I use margarine, it is a thinner base, and does not separate.  But we prefer butter and sometimes it separates, no matter what I did!  I found after finishing, rather than adding the last bit of milk, if I use a bit of the water from boiling the pasta, it smooths out, and blends perfectly!!!   My ONLY change is a personal one, we prefer roasted garlic to the powder.  I roast garlic every couple of weeks, and I squeeze a couple of cloves into this and it is AHHHHMAZING!!!

text:
I find this recipe through an ingredient search. With limited ingredients on hand, I couldn't make  my usual sauce. Wow, how lucky can you get? I did saute garlic and onion in my butter per preference. I also roasted some tomatoes in olive oil, salt, pepper and garlic; parboiled some broccoli. OMG, even the hubs, who hates anything Italian, couldn't stop raving bout the sauce.  He ate his entire plate.  I did not use med heat when adding the cream cheese, but low heat. I continued low heat when adding the milk. BTW, I used reconstituted evaporated milk . There was no taste of cream cheese.......only a perfect sauce. This second-generation Italian now has a shortcut to a perfect sauce.  Buon mangiare i miei amici

text:
Amazing! I am not buying Alfredo sauce anymore! I used garlic salt with parsley. The would suggest reducing the milk to 1 2/3 - 1 3/4 for a thicker sauce. Too much Parmesan and the sauce ends up tasting grainy so I wouldn’t change the original amount unless that is what you want. For a richer taste, I would use half and half. Taste of cream cheese was not noticeable at all.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this recipe a few times now, and I just love it. The cream cheese gives it a great velvety texture without being super heavy, like some traditional alfredo sauces can be. If the cream cheese flavor is too overwhelming, just add more parmesan! I followed the recipe pretty much to the letter, except i used minced garlic instead of powdered, and added a healthy pinch of salt and oregano to add a little more depth of flavor.
I've also used this sauce as a base for a pasta bake and it was phenomenal.  I tossed with rotini, diced chicken sausage, spinach and roasted red peppers and topped with a little shredded mozzarella- bake in a casserole dish for 30min at 350. Delicious!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1197784.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this so many times and writing this review as I make it again. I make into a Cajun Chicken Alfredo, but this base sauce recipe is amazing! Don’t let your butter or cream cheese get too warm or it will separate (NOTE: it is still good when this happens, but it’s a thousand times better when you go low and slow). I mince some garlic and add into the butter (before the cream cheese). The Parmesan part can be tricky, but when you’re stirring it, if you see it’s starting to thicken up around whatever you’re stirring with, that’s exactly what you want. Be patient and it’ll come out perfectly! If you want to try a Cajun kick, use Tony Cachere’s Creole Seasoning (I like the “more spice”).
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
Easy Peasy and Delicious! Made as written, except only a half recipe due to what I had on hand.  Had with chicken and gluten free penne! Couldn’t have asked for anything better! I did read the reviews prior to making and appreciated someone saying not to worry about the cream cheese looking lumpy until you whisk in the milk.  I did make the mistake of making it too early, as I couldn’t believe it would be that quick. But, I am now a believer!  Will time it out better next time. And, all the times after that, as this recipe is definitely a keeper!

This is my go-to Alfredo recipe. Much better and just as easy as any store bought brand. I don't whisk, I put the cream cheese and milk in the blender and put it into a pot that has minced garlic sauteed in butter.  Once the sauce is thickened to my liking I add LOTS of pepper and parmesan. Done!!

text:
10.16.18 ... https://www.allrecipes.com/recipe/19402/quick-and-easy-alfredo-sauce/ ... While I liked this, I probably won't make again. I thought it was going to be "quick & easy."  It wasn't any quicker or easier than the real deal using butter, cream & parmesan cheese.  I couldn't see the cream cheese thickening two cups of milk so subbed one of those cups with half & half.  It still didn't & I thickened with 1T cornstarch.  Maybe it was the cheese, but before thickening it was melted cheese on the bottom & eversoslightly cheesy milk on top.  I added the parmesan very slowly.  I made it to use with this ... https://www.allrecipes.com/recipe/23425/pesto-lasagna/ ... because I'm certain freshly made three ingredient alfredo would separate.  'Surprised this didn't taste like cream cheese.  'Would've been okay, if it did though.  'Tastes like alfredo.  :)   I didn't add any garlic or pepper & used unsalted butter.

text:
Good but would be better with half heavy whipping cream and half milk but since I didn't have any cream, I decided to look for a quick recipe that uses only milk. 
Changes I made :
Minced garlic in place of powder.
Added about a 1/3 cup of flour after melting the cream cheese because we like ours thicker. 
Then I doubled the milk.
And of course added chicken!!
It was a little too cream cheesy for my liking but my kids devoured it.  Next time I make it I'll half the cream cheese and I'm sure it will be prefect.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow this was delicious.  And fairly easy to make, once I got past My own mistakes and faulty cookware.  Will definitely make this again (and again)!

I have to recommend using whole milk and real butter; that's actually in most recipes but particularly in one such as this one, where those ingredients are so important.  Also, if you have the time/energy/equipment, I cannot tell you how superior freshly grated Parmesan cheese is to the store bought Kraft stuff.  The difference is very pronounced.

I made a double batch and used one 8-oz wedge of Parmesan.  I also slightly reduced the amount of milk (I didn't actually MEAN to do that, but the container I put the milk in before adding it to the pot leaked a little).  Also used fresh ground black pepper, as in everything I eat or cook.  Buying a pepper grinder at the store is really not that much more expensive than a pepper shaker, and it makes a world of difference.

One thing that did horrify Me in the instructions though: using a wire whisk in a non-stick pot.  NO!  NO!  A thousand times NO!  Just use a wooden spoon or a non-metal whisk unless you feel like replacing your pot frequently, since metal utensils scratch up the non-stick coating unless you're REALLY careful.

All in all, this turned out even better than I could have imagined.  I used it on some pasta with freshly sliced mushrooms and a sprinkle more of Parmesan (just a sprinkle, so I did use the store-bought Kraft in this instance).  Absolute heaven.  It's like an

text:
A great base. I added 5 chopped cloves of garlic with the butter, I was a little short on cream cheese,  my milk (2%) was slightly sour, and about 1/6th of my butter was old herbed butter. I also subbed Monterey Jack cheese (sue me), which I'm guessing is why it didn't thicken up much, and I don't own a whisk (sue me) so I used a wooden salad-tossing-fork.  Served with spinach tortelloni and a pinot noir (I like a bold red with a fatty dish) and it was great. Delicious and surprisingly forgiving, considering my weird off-balance ingredient situation, though the final texture was a little grainy. Maybe I cooked it too long after adding the cheese? This is a great way to use up dairy products that are about to go bad, and can handle improvisation. Did not taste like cream cheese,  but maybe ease up on the milk if you're using a softer cheese.

city:

country:
None
text:
This is really good and incredibly easy recipe.  I swapped out 1/2 cup of 2% milk for heavy cream and it was divine.   I also used fresh garlic (about 1 TBSP) that I added to the melting butter.  Before you start hating me for changing a recipe and rating it, I had to get rid of the heavy cream before it went bad. 

Also - for those that are saying that cream cheese shouldn't be used, cream cheese can be used in most recipes as substitute for heavy cream as long as the recipe doesn't require the cream to be whipped.  I didn't taste cream cheese at all.

One really good tip that I could have used... this makes a ton of sauce.  Easily enough for 2 pounds of pasta (pre cooking weight).  I cooked only a small package of pasta, and had to cook a second box just to have enough pasta for the sauce.

I also threw in some grilled chicken and it was excellent together.  Great recipe and much  easier than traditional alfredo.

text:
Eh, it was okay. The problem, in my opinion, is that the name is wrong. It is "Easy Cream Cheese Sauce" *not* Alfredo sauce. My teenage son liked it. But having worked in a restaurant that served high quality authentic Alfredo, I can say that this just is not like the real thing. To the "lumpy" reviewers - use a whisk! Make sure the heat is not too high, too. This is more of a college student in a hurry recipe, not a bring guests over for Alfredo recipe.

text:
A word of warning: this recipe calls for an absurd amount of garlic, and believe me, I love my garlic! I probably used half of a teaspoon and it was more than enough. I also didn't have enough regular cream cheese, so I used whipped cream cheese and it still turned out great. It will look gross and scary while you're mixing the cream cheese and butter together, but it will magically turn into a perfect, creamy sauce as soon as you add the milk. This is great for people who are bad at making sauces, like me! Everyone loved it!

text:
I've made it twice, and will certainly make it again and again!!!  I add grilled chicken, sautéed portabella mushrooms and sometimes cooked asparagus.  You can use this recipe and add whatever you want and it will be great (bacon for a carbonara or pancetta).  Just delicious and easy!!!  Almost an everyday recipe since it is so easy!!!  Grilling chicken or making the pasta takes longer than the sauce, plus this is a recipe that you can double or triple without giving up the taste!!!  Great for a leftover, just add a bit more milk so it isn't too thick!  This is now one of my "go to" recipes!!!  Be creative and enjoy it!  Even a bit of red pepper flakes to add some heat!!!

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3124912.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
LOVE how easy  this is! I followed the recipe exactly the first time. This time I sauteed 1 small onion and 2 garlic cloves in butter. Then added a few finely chopped mushrooms and sauteed until they were cooked through. Then I added 2 cups of frozen peas and about 3/4 cup cubed up roasted chicken breast.  I let that heat through about 4 minutes then transferred it to a bowl. I used the same skillet to follow the original recipe but cut the amount of garlic powder in half. After the cheese was added, I added a Tablespoon of chopped parsley and a few grinds of black pepper. Then I stirred the chicken breast mixture back in.  Just as it started to bubble, I took it off the heat and added it to hot pasta.

text:
I have made this recipe a ton of times over the past 9 years and it never fails that I need to make a second batch just to finish making the meal. Everyone comes and uses it as a dip with French bread, chips, or cut veggies and my husband has me make it for his specialty lasagna. I went a bit further and took a 10-12.5 oz can of chicken and saute it in a drizzle of olive oil, minced garlic and fresh sliced onions on low while the sauce and pasta finish up then mix it into the sauce. Pour the combo over any kind of macaroni you want and garnish with a dash of paprika (for color)!

userID:
4663806
Display Name:
AZ435
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
11
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674151.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was making a baked ziti recipe that called for a jar of Alfredo sauce, so I decided to make my own. One weird thing, I only have soy milk, and I didn't feel that would work here. So for the milk, I took a regular can of cream of chicken soup, and diluted with water to make 2 cups.  Instead of garlic powder, I sautéed 2 crushed cloves of garlic in the butter, along with 1/2 tsp of Italian Seasoning (herbs) and a dash of ground nutmeg.  I melted in 8 oz of low-fat cream cheese, then took the pan off the heat while I incorporated the parmesan using a whisk. (Adding the parmesan at this stage, and off the heat, avoids lumps and sticking to the pan.) At this point, it's a clumpy mess lol. Then I gradually whisked in the diluted soup (or milk if you're using that) over med-low heat. Despite being ugly in the early stages, this became the most lovely, velvety Alfredo sauce ever! Follow these directions and you won't go wrong. Note: My family really likes garlic, so you might want to start with one clove the first time if you're not sure.

text:
This recipe was easy and gave that rich, creamy flavor a good Alfredo Sauce should have (without the heavy cream).  I used low-fat cream cheese and added 1 Tablespoon of dry vermouth (like white wine) to give it a tangy, savory spin.  Half of the recipe makes enough for 2 different meals for a couple...  I used it as a side over linguini served with grilled fish and for the next meal tossed with shrimp,veggies and rotelli pasta.  Next time I might add some freshly-grated nutmeg since it'll compliment the cheese so well.  It kept well in the refrigerator for a week.

text:
It is a very good starter recipe, but we found it quite bland as is.  We tweaked it to: 
2 chicken breasts cubed 
Only 1/2 cont. cream cheese 
Roasted garlic - 2 cloves + a little garlic powder
1 TBS Italian spices
1 cup Parmesan 
Broccoli, carrots, and peapods (frozen mixed bag)
2-4 TBS flour with sauce for thickener before adding cheese & veggies.  My daughter & husband said it was better than any restaurant Chicken Alfredo they'd ever had.

text:
I made this last night to use with some penne pasta and pan fried chicken breast. It was so delicious! Tasted better than any restaurant dish I've had (of chicken Alfredo). I ended up using about a third of the Parmesan called for because that's all I had, and double the margarine (recipe calls for butter, but the oiliness of margarine really helps the flavor and texture in my opinion). I had my burner on too hot so I also ended up using more milk to even it out. The end result was wonderful and cheesy and smooth

None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Turned out great. Very creamy. But I made a few modifications. Used 3/4 stick of butter instead of an entire stick & one 12oz can low fat (2%) evaporated milk instead of 16oz regular milk. Only used 6oz low fat cream cheese instead of 8oz full fat cc. And I combined Parmesan Reggiano with Locatelli cheese, both freshly grated. Added cooked chicken pieces, steamed broccoli & angel hair pasta. Very tasty.

country:

text:
It was ok/good.   Mainly it was really bland.

I did have to make some substitutions for health reasons.  Full fat cream cheese became light cream cheese.  6 oz of Parm (I use the real very salty stuff) was changed to 4 oz of Mozzarella & 2 oz of Parmesan.  I don't think that was an issue though, it tasted like alfredo.  I cracked a lot of pepper, added some salt and it was ok.  The texture was great.  The flavor was close, but again...it was kinda bland.  May have been my fault for substituting Moz.  but seriously, 6 oz of Parm (with all that salt) and all that butter seemed like it would be too rich.  Anyway, I'm ranking it as "Good" since it was "OK" with substitutions.

text:
I gave this 4 stars because it makes a great base sauce but needs help to make it an awesome sauce. I doubled this sauce for two adults and three children( we like left overs). Besides what the basic list of ingredients I added 2 cups of heavy whipping creme, 6 small to medium sized gloves of garlic finely minced, 2 sticks of unsalted butter, and a cup of finely grated Parmesan cheese. I also added a teaspoon of cilantro, oregano, Mediterranean basil. overall the family loved the sauce.

text:
This recipe is fantastic. My picky eaters love it. Don't make the mistake I did by listening to those who say to add more cheese. It was too strong so I ended up almost having to double everything else. I did use the suggestion of 1 cup of half and half and 1 cup of milk, I also added a touch oregano. The consistency was perfect, no separation like some talked about, although I did whisk nonstop for about 15 minutes. I will absolutely make this again!

text:
This is a good substitute to traditional Alfredo sauce when you are fresh out of cream. Please please please use fresh, REAL Parmesan cheese. Not the pre shredded or stuff in a container, it truly makes all the difference.   The nice thing about this sauce is that it doesn't seperate upon reheating like the traditional Alfredo.  Also, fresh garlic is always better, I used 5 cloves.   My family really enjoyed it over spinach ravioli.

text:
This was great!  I was looking for something to make with the ingredients I had in the house.  I used neufchatel cheese (french cream cheese), reduced the garlic to 1 teaspoon, used part skim milk & part whole milk (next time i will decrease the amount of milk slightly), and the big change was I used 1 cup mozzarella cheese and just sprinkled in grated Parmesan.  I would have used fresh grated Parmesan, but was out.  It turned out so well!  I'm going to throw away my traditional recipe.  I tend to have cream cheese in the house, but not usually heavy cream.  I find the jar Alfredo awful, but I feel this was quality of a restaurant.  My husband loved it too.  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
This was so delicious! I did change a couple things (which I know people hate, but oh well)... I used lots of minced garlic (the jarred kind) instead of powder because I like garlicky Alfredo. I also only added milk until it was the right consistency. I made it once with the recommended amount andit was too runny. Great flavor and super fast! Also, it warmed up the next day well without getting oily like a traditional Alfredo.

text:
This recipe was fantastic! My 7-yo son and I made this together. I thought it would be an easy recipe for him to follow. We followed it exactly and it turned out great. The only thing was that the sauce was a little grainy, but in fairness, I was was preparing it with a 7-yo who is still learning patience, so had we let it go a little longer it would have probably been perfectly smooth. It was a little thicker than my personal taste, so we did add additional milk to thin it out, but this does come down to personal taste. I did not find it to taste more like cream cheese as some of the reviews stated. We sautéed some shrimp in lemon, garlic, and evoo to compliment the sauce. My 7-yo loved it, as well as, my 10 yo. We will definitely be doing this recipe again. Next time, we may use some of the other suggestions like adding nutmeg and using part heavy cream in place of the milk, however on fairness to reviewing this recipe, we made is exactly as written and it was very good.

userID:
18223410
Display Name:
JessieB
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My boyfriend loves Spinach pizza, but it called for white sauce. Rather than giving up and getting a jar, I decided to look up a recipe in hopes of finding an easy one to use. I decided on this one, and I'm glad I did. He said it was the best pizza he had ever had, and begs me to make it again all the time!

Be forwarned, the cream cheese could be an aquired taste. There is a bit of a zing to it, as is the usual case with cream cheese. If you like cream cheese, it shouldn't bother you. But if you don't, you may want to consider another recipe.

I did go with pre-shredded parmasean, and even though people say to always do it fresh, I feel that with pizza, using the canned stuff was a good call. I didn't want the cheese in the sauce to be overpowering, since it was going to be covered with mozzerella cheese anyway. The blandness worked in out favor. However, definitly get FRESH parmasean if you're making this for pasta, which won't get a mozzerella boost like pizza will.

text:
Best alfredo sauce I have ever tried.  I used just a stick of butter because I added bacon oil (I wanted meat in my pasta) I didn't have a whisk so I just used a wooden spoon.  I was afraid that the cream cheese would be just fried in the butter but adding the milk slowly made the mixture blend together eventually.  You just need to be patient.  Garlic powder and fresh parsley gave this sauce a nice blend of flavor.  This makes is a very good base sauce for any white sauce recipe.  I can imagine using this for tuna fettuccine or chicken breast + broccoli.  I will definitely make this again.

userID:
18030713
Display Name:
Trish Glavin
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3572401.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This alfredo sauce was DELICIOUS and is now my go to recipe!  Thick, creamy, full of flavor and very easy to make.  I followed some of Reg927's recipe tweeks:  1 tsp minced garlic with the butter,  1 1/3 cups milk, and about 1/4 tsp black pepper and a few grinds of sea salt.  I had no trouble melting the Parmesan cheese into the mixture (and I used shaved Parmesan).  The cream cheese is an ingenious ingredient; nice flavor but you don't know there's cream cheese in the final product.  My only advice:  whisk, whisk, whisk.  Don't leave ingredients to melt; whisk them gently together from beginning to end and be patient.  It will all come together.  I found the act of standing there and whisking quite calming.
Review:
Rating:
5

I don't know that it was any faster than a traditional alfredo but it's a keeper for me because I'm much more likely to have these ingredients in my fridge than a pint of heavy cream. Overall, great easy dinner recipe and the kids gobbled it up.

78551
Display Name:
Marilyn Krupa-Burns

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2669927.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an excellent base for Alfredo sauce. What I did to beef it up a bit was to add Basil (didn't have fresh, so used dried). I started with 1/4 tsp., whisked it in, added a wee bit more (by the pinch) until I got the level of Basil that I liked.  I also added a scant 1/4 tsp. of ground nutmeg, some chopped freeze-dried Italian parsley.  I did up the Parmesan to 1 cup, though.  I was making Italian stuffed chicken breasts and instead of using a marinara sauce on top, I topped it with some of this sauce after baking them sprinkled with more Parmesan cheese before baking.  The remainder of the sauce I added to Fettucine, after blending in some steamed chopped broccoli for a side dish.  Serve with a crusty Italian bread, some herb-olive oil for dunking the bread and an Italian salad--complete meal!
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
Let me start by saying that I'm not a cook. I don't like to cook, and I'm not good at it. But, I need to save money and get healthier, so staying at home it is. Today, I needed some creamy alfredo to soothe my sore throat, and I was about to call pizza hut for a pasta bake when I saw this and decided to give it a try. So easy and so delicious. My two-year-old is scarfing it down. No doubt much healthier than pizza hut (used 2% milk) and much better tasting. I made the recipe according to the directions, but I used minced garlic - not garlic powder - and fresh shredded Parmesan from the artisan cheese section. This recipe helped to build my confidence!

Not everything needs to be gourmet, or exotic or twee. Folks, I had cream cheese in the house and little else. This recipe worked well. But do heed the warning that the sauce will thicken =quickly=. I only had the cheaper, powdery Parm cheese and I wouldn't recommend that; I couldn't get a perfectly smooth texture. A hearty meal for anyone in a pinch. Thanks!

text:
This recipe is a keeper.  I did add garlic salt instead of the powder,  dash of ground nutmeg, onion powder and dried oregano.  I just love dried oregano.  I also added fresh spinach.  This is very forgiving and you can add any kind of protein or veggie.
It was very creamy and not heavy.  This is  the first time I used cream cheese when making alfredo sauce and it was great.
If the sauce gets too thick, you can always add pasta water to it.  I added a few ladles.

Well after finding out my G/F liked Alfredo and I wanted to do something a little more special on Valentines Eve then jar Alfredo I decided to try this recipe with Linguini .  I also picked up a jar of Alfredo just as a backup.  Well certainly didn't need any backup as this recipe was awesome.  She even wanted to take the rest home with her.  

I don't know why people are saying they can taste the cream cheese.  I couldn't at all.  I did have to make one modification, it called for Roasted Garlic and Olive oil butter from L.O.L. I didn't see that so I used just the L.O.L. Butter with Olive oil.  I will also try minced Garlic next time instead of Garlic Powder.

I have another recipe I prefer that calls for less butter, only 3 oz of cream cheese, 1 to 1 1/2 cups of 2% milk, more parmesan and fresh parsley (and I add a bit of white wine). I think next time we'll go back to that one.

text:
This is honestly the best Alfredo I have EVER had! Better than any jar, restaurant or recipe. The only things I did different was use 3 cloves of fresh garlic, a bit of fresh parsley and I stirred the parmasean in to the cream cheese before the milk.  It was smooth and flavourful with no separation and did NOT taste at all like cream cheese! This recipe yields ALOT of sauce. Probably enough for 2 meals. And that's great! Because it is soooo good!

text:
This was very good and I will make again.  I did tweak it slightly based on the other reviews. Instead of garlic powder, I sautéed a clove of garlic with the butter. I also sprinkled some black pepper after everything was melted together.  For this recipe I used skim milk and Romano cheese instead of Parmesan because I prefer the taste.  Also, as another reviewer suggested, whisk, whisk, whisk! I mixed it with cooked chicken and broccoli and put it over whole wheat pasta.  Great "Alfredo" recipe with just the basic items you might already have in your kitchen.

I tried this recipe because I lacked cream, but did have cream cheese to hand. This sauce has a pleasant taste and was nice over pasta with peas for a quick dinner. Unlike some others here, I don't feel that this tastes like an authentic Alfredo, nor would I describe it as "superb" or "excellent" but good nonetheless.  I also felt the sauce tasted heavily of cream cheese, but, as I love cream cheese, this was not a bad thing at all and I  ended up adding additional cream cheese to it.  I also did not have powdered garlic btw, and so used fresh garlic instead. All in all, more like a cream cheese sauce than an Alfredo, but good  for a quick weeknight supper!

Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2015-08-16T05:35:31.553
helpfulCount:

userID:
2304291
Display Name:
Misa Rillo
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
12
favoritesCount:
7
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2328696.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I wanted to make an Alfredo sauce, but didn't have heavy cream on hand which I usually use, so came on here and thought perhaps the cream cheese would make a tasty sauce (though perhaps not an authentic Alfredo sauce.) Some negative reviewers say their cream cheese curdled...cream cheese will not actually curdle/go bad, though it might separate and the texture of the sauce might have some lumps...In my sauce I used butter and the cream cheese did separate a bit when initially added but when I added the milk and my freshly-grated Parmesan it all melted smoothly together. One thing is probably key...use freshly grated Parmesan cheese. That junk that is pregrated has ingredients in it to prevent it from clumping together in the package, which also prevents the cheese from melting smoothly in a sauce recipe (same with other pregrated or preshredded cheeses...these are okay as toppings for things like tacos, but terrible for melting/using in sauces). This recipe didn't taste overwhelmingly of cream cheese, imho, as some stated, it wasn't quite "Authentic Alfredo" either, but it was a nice, tasty, creamy, easy sauce with ingredients I almost always have on hand so I will likely make it again.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2015-08-10T13:33:38.593
helpfulCount:

It was very very easy to make I did do alor of adding to it. Adding sautéed mushrooms, red peppers, red onion, and shrimp. The whisk is a must have and you have to be prep
 To keep stirring. I did have a small problem with the parmesan being grainy but I added heavy cream and more milk and turned the heat up a tad and that solved that. It was smooth and the en the added ingredient OMG. My boyfriend loved and just keeps raving about my cooking now. This one will DEFINITELY stay in my head.

I love this recipe! The only change I make is using 1 teaspoon minced garlic instead of 2 teaspoons powered. I just prefer minced. Sometimes I cook a pound of ground chicken in another pan and add it this sauce when it's finished for a simple chicken Alfredo. This makes a lot of sauce. I can mix it with an entire box of cooked pasta and it coats all of it. I do not but jar Alfredo sauce anymore since finding this recipe. :-)

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6937904.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So it's not authentic, but five stars because this is so yummy, easy and used ingredients on hand when I didn't have cream. This also has fewer calories than a full cream version, especially if neufchatel is used. I have made a number of times now, once subbing Pecorino Romano for the Parmesan. I learned not to sub a slicing cheese...it clumps, but I managed to salvage a batch made with provalone by stirring in 2 tablespoons of roux (2 Tbsp. butter & flour cooked together) which dissolved the clumps, and I added a few ounces of Parm at the end.  My picky grandkids, 5, 7 & 8,  lap this up each time, even with canned clams added to the mix. It is one of the dishes they request on a regular basis.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/166172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Makes a lot! I will probably have enough for 2 different recipes (the one I used it for and then one other). (UPDATE: I did have enough for both of my recipes).

I didn't make any changes, made exactly as the recipe states. I did use fresh grated Parmesan rather than the pre-packaged stuff though. 

UPDATE: With the first recipe I made, a Pesto Alfredo Chicken pasta casserole it was great, but the pesto added a lot of flavor. But with just plain chicken fettuccine Alfredo it was a little bit bland. Next time I'm going to try adding some oregano, garlic salt, and minced garlic (we love our garlic here lol).

P.S. This freezes great! After making this for my initial recipe I had about 12oz left over and I froze it in a freezer-safe container. To re-heat I heated it in a saucepan over low heat and added a splash of milk. It came out great! So if you're a make-and-freeze kind of person, this is a great recipe for that.

text:
I was asked to bring Alfredo sauce to a community spaghetti dinner, but there was a problem. I had never made it before, so I went looking for a recipe when I stumbled upon this one. It was amazing! I made it exactly as written, but had no milk, so in my double recipe used three cups half and half and a cup of water with a little more to thin. I made it on the stove and it took almost a half hour. When it was ready, I put it in a crockpot on low to serve. Everyone loved it and asked for the recipe.

text:
Cooking for kiddos can be a challenge. Especially if you want to feed them whole, healthy foods. This recipe was an absolute winner for us. My 2 and 4 year old gobbled every bite. I put broccoli in for veg but you could easily put peas or carrots. If you scan your dairy aisles for items with less than 5 ingredients (all of which you can pronounce) you can easily make this and feel very good about serving it. For garlic powder I used fresh garlic but, either way, it's such a small amount I don't think anyone would feel guilty about it. It's not gourmet but it will get even picky eaters to eat everything you mix with it!

clmccullers06

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just made this tonight and put it over penne with chicken and broccoli. It was amazing. My littlest little is somewhat of an alfredo connoisseur and told me that this on was way better than her fav hometown restaurant that makes their sauce fresh from scratch everyday (she won't even touch alfredo from a jar). I did make a couple changes just because it was what I had on hand but it was smooth, creamy and totally "alfredo-y." I used neufchatel instead of regular cream cheese and shredded parmesan rather than the grated. In my opinion, the grated never melts or blends just right. The shredded worked into the sauce beautifully although it did take a bit longer and a little more wisking. I used one cup heavy cream and one cup low fat milk (1%) rather than straight milk. I didn't have any garlic powder, however, I used 3 medium sized cloves fresh garlic chopped tiny and sauteed in the butter for awhile before I added anything else. I did otherwise follow the directions to a T and couldn't be happier, especially for my first time making alfredo from scratch! :)
