text:
I know people don't want to hear how this tastes altered but I was just looking for a guide to making the sauce.  I was cooking for one so I didn't follow the measurements but I did follow the ingredients except for using minced garlic instead of powder. It was delicious and I think the cream cheese is a great addition since it may help the sauce stick to the pasta.  I wanted chicken with my alfredo penne pasta so I cut boneless breasts into bite sized pieces and sauteed them in olive oil and butter and seasoned the chicken in the pan with McCormicks Perfect Pinch Roasted Garlic and Bell Pepper Seasoning, salt and pepper and a dash of red pepper flakes. The chicken came out delicious and didn't go into the pasta as bland cooked chicken.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1303864.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this alfredo recipe. It tastes like quality alfredo, contrary to what some have stated. The key to a good alfredo sauce is high quality ingredients. Use real butter, real milk (not skim), fresh grated parmesan (not canned), grate a bit of garlic (instead of powdered) and finally use Neufchatel cheese, rather than cream. All my ingredients were also organic, but that's not necessary. Heat it VERY slowly and keep the heat very low throughout and everything will blend just fine. Fresh, quality ingredients are key to this recipe yielding a quality sauce!
Review:
Rating:
5

I have been using the exact recipe for several years now, however, about 2 weeks ago I wanted to make it but I was out of Parmesan cheese. The only change I made was using fresh garlic instead of powder.  Those who didn't rate this recipe 4+ stars must have missed a step.  I like this better than any alfredo I've tasted at restaurants before as I generally prefer a tomato based sauce.  Used this recipe for baked gnocchi, will be using it again in many other ways!  Thanks!

text:
Instead of using garlic powder I used real garlic (2 cloves) and grated it up. I also substituted some shredded mozzarella cheese for some of the parmesan since I had the Kraft stuff and didn't want to use it all up. I did't measure it but went by consistency of the sauce. I thought it was delicious and my family enjoyed it too. Much much tastier than the sauce from jars. After I finished making the sauce I added a few big hand fulls of spinach, grilled chicken, and roasted red pepper (brushed with oil and put on the BBQ). Would have added mushrooms but didn't have any around.

userID:
3437921
Display Name:
Chris Hogan
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677179.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I really like this sauce.  It's easy & has only a few ingredients.  I did tweak it, as so many do.  I chopped a clove of fresh garlic and let it mellow with the butter as it melted over low heat.  Then I whisked in about 2 tablespoons of the cream cheese (I thought 8 oz might be too much for my taste)I gradually whisked in 1 3/4 cups of milk,then the cheese (I mixed Romano & Parmesan, because it is what I had on hand.  I like a thicker sauce, so I stirred 2 Tbsp cornstarch with the last 1/4 cup of milk, added it to the sauce and let it bubble until it was thick! Add some salt & pepper to taste...GREAT!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
We just made this per the recipe but scaled down to one serving.  It has been too many decades ago and too few times that I have been exposed to what was very good Alfredo Sauce so I can't comment on its authenticity.  What I can comment on is that it went together very smoothly and tasted great. (Use your good Parmesan.) 

We used it as the sauce on a chicken and roasted garlic pizza (red bell pepper for color and black olives for comic relief).  A quarter batch was more than enough for a 12" pizza.  

This won't supplant red sauce as top dog on our pasta/pizza but it will add variety to our menu.  It is worthy of a company dish.

What would I change? Non è una cosa.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/11148.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I enjoyed this recipe.  I used about 1.5 c milk and 1/2 c heavy cream because I wanted to use it up.  I also used about 8 ounces grated parmesan - I used the 2nd smallest size on my multi-size cheese grater.  When adding the liquid, I added about 1/4 c at a time, whisking constantly.  I also added the parmesan by pinches, whisking constantly.  It came out with a smooth, enjoyable texture that way.  Next time, I might add more garlic and more pepper.  

What I liked most about this sauce is that, unlike almost all other alfredo sauces that seem to become chunky and thick before I'm done trying to eat, this stayed smooth in consistency until the last bite.  Yum!

Lschaefer67

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is very good and very easy to make.  I usually tweak recipes a lot but followed this fairly closely. I didn't have any fresh garlic  which I would have preferred, so I used the powder instead.
It takes a little patience to make...I would tell other people who had trouble to let the cream cheese soften slightly before starting to cook, cut it into smaller blocks so its easier to combine. Once the cream cheese breaks down in the pan (part way) add a small amount of milk and whisk. Add the milk bit by bit and continue to whisk.
And lastly....use REAL Parmesan or Pecorino Romano (I prefer Romano)...it may be more expensive but its so much better than that junk in the green can - buy a block and grate it yourself, your taste buds and your dinner guests will thank you!! You will also see that the sauce doesn't come out gritty at all....the Parmesan should melt very easily wi no grit. 
So, overall...I'm not a fan of cheese or cream sauces but this was tasty, was not overly rich and most importantly, everyone in my family of 5 will eat it, so this will become an addition to our monthly meal plan! Thanks for posting!!

Because I wanted to rate it based on the exact recipe I am giving it a 4. I didn't change a thing even after reading a lot of the ratings. What I found that is was a little "too cheesy" for me. text:
It was good, but no rave reviews from this reviewer.  This is not the best Alfredo sauce I've ever tasted, I'd still rather have a Buca Alfredo or similar; but it is better than the canned options out there. I can see why some would say this is bland. I used a lot (almost the entire) Parmesan cheese container and added some Mozzarella cheese as well-- salt and pepper.  It was definitely creamy and smooth-- but to achieve this a whisk is needed or I could see this becoming a gloopy mess, and it helps keep the mixture from burning to the bottom of your saucepan. I would try again to continue to tweak-- probably the addition of chicken would help.

text:
This turned out really well for me. The only thing I did differently was to add some crushed garlic to the butter and let it cook for a couple of minutes before adding the cream cheese (careful not to let the garlic burn or it will ruin your sauce). I omitted the garlic powder since I used fresh. I also added a pinch of nutmeg at the end. Was creamy, garlicy, and super easy. My boyfriend usually doesn't eat creamy sauces and he loved this. Will definitely make this again!

text:
I''m a newbie cook, so new that in trying the recipes out i usually take twice the amount of time to prepare and cook, and blotch the entire thing 1 out of 3 tries. So i usually try the easy recipes with affordable ingredients (you dont want to use expensive ingredients if you have a good chance of failing, ha!)

Anyways, i cooked this for my boyfriend and he loved it! I loved it! Quoting: "It's really good. Congratulations. It's restaurant level pasta. If you undercook the pasta a little, its Mamu (famous high end restaurant here innthe Philippines that serve great pasta and steak) level pasta. Im proud of you." 

Notes: 
In the original recipe, Parmesan was used instead of cheddar but we like the cheddar more coz its saltier. And  1 teaspoon garlic powder was recommnded but since i didnt have garlic powder, i used real garlic instead. 

So for future use (definitely!), i'll stick to cheddar and undercook the pasta a little. And i agree, the cream cheese really is the magic ingredient!!

Great recipe!  This is exactly what I was looking for.  It is a creamy cheesy sauce, so different from the bland Alfredo sauces I've tried before.  Best of all, it is easy to prepare.

I ended up not using all of the milk (maybe about 1 cup) and adding some salt.  Also, I didn't have any garlic powder, so I added in some fresh minced chives at the very end of cooking.  I also added some frozen peas near the end of cooking for color and texture though that may not be to everyone's taste.  Next time, I might saute some onions and mushrooms and add them, too.

text:
I had to use part butter part margarine, but it was good. A little salty by itself, but good for flavoring the noodles and broccoli. I guess I don't eat the sauce by itself anyway, except for tasting. Lol.mine looked clumpy until milk was in, but thinned out beautifully.  I did low- medium until the milk was added, then turned to low, stirring occasionally, and it thickened a little, then turned off heat, and just left it on the burner, and it has a great consistency. Will make again.

LOVE LOVE LOVE this recipe. I have made it so many times because it is so good, so quick (seriously), and most importantly you can make it reduced fat. 
I used less than half of the butter than it called for, and it still tasted amazing. I also 1/3 reduced fat cream cheese and skim milk and with these two changes it was still thick and creamy. 
This is my new go to because I usually have all of the ingredients and it is seriously so quick and honestly so delicious!

text:
I was a bit skeptical at first after seeing cream cheese in this recipe and thinking that was so not the flavor I would want in an alfredo, but I was very pleasantly surprised at how well this tasted!  The key thing is to just keep whisking because it will look kinda weird at first and you just have to be patient.  The only extra thing I did was to add just a sprinkle of nutmeg because I really love that element of flavor in an alfredo.  This is an easy, delicious recipe that I'll be keeping!  Thanks for sharing! :-)

It wasn't still an okay consistency, and still tasted good, but I'd give it 5 stars if it would've worked out just as nicely (or, if the recipe called for margarine, instead).

None
text:
This is a great recipe for Alfredo sauce. The only thing different I do is I add another tsp of garlic powder, leave out the pepper, and use less milk. I don't measure the milk I just put enough in to make it thick and creamy. If I have any leftover, which is usually not the case as my family loves this, I do need to add more milk. It becomes pretty solid after it is refrigerated, because I don't use as much milk as the recipe calls for. When my kids' friends come for dinner they always ask, "are you making Alfredo tonight?"

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this last night with Grilled chicken Ravioli from Sam's because I didn't have any Alfredo Sauce on hand. I LOVED it! I did read the reviews and make the changes suggested....1 tsp minced garlic with the butter, only used about 1 1/3 cups milk and 4 oz. of parmesean (half a container of kraft grated), about 1/4 tsp black pepper and a few grinds of sea salt. Next time, I would probably add a little more parmesan...maybe the 6 oz. It also did not thicken quickly, it took a good 5-10 minutes. 

I will definitely not be buying canned sauce again! The cream cheese does give it a little of a different flavor than traditional Alfredo, but it is a really good white sauce to use with your Italian dishes!

Ok, so I can't eat dairy right now because I'm breastfeeding and my baby can't tolerate it. Alfredo is my favorite food group and i was dying without it. I was able to find a vegan cream cheese spread, and vegan grated parmesean topping. i subbed almond milk for regular milk. I did use the butter, but probably would have been ok subbing olive oil if needed to be completely dairy free. It was pretty good. Only slightly worse than the dairy version. I'm giving this 4 stars because I have an amazing alfredo recipe that no other recipe can beat, and I can't wait to get back to making that one!

text:
mmmmm Yum!! This was excellent! I made a few changes because I didn't have the right kind of cheese and I just wanted to add my own flare:) I used grated gouda cheese, tamari sauce, extra garlic (minced and powder) a fresh variety of herbs and chopped onion and chicken sauteed in raw organic coconut oil. I aslo added a couple pinches of cayenne powder to give a slight kick. Everyone loved it! I really knew it was good when my 18 year old brother went to the stove and started scraping out the pan and asking me if I could make it again tomorrow :) Very good and simple recipe that would be good by itself but is also a great starter for your style alfredo!

text:
Always wondered how they did that sauce with those one skillet meals...now I know. It's not that bad that I would  not do it again if I needed a fast and very simple alfredo sauce, as in a sudden menu change. However I would not use this recipe to attempt to demonstrate my skills making sauces. To me it simply doesn't have a lot of zing or make a very strong impression. I would use minced garlic and very coarsely ground pepper for starters. Like I said it's a beginning but leaves a lot of room for improvisations and improvement, but I did save it for future tweaking!

text:
I was really in a pinch when I did a search for this recipe. I had just finished making some oven baked chicken and some cheese tortellini when I realized I didn't have any Alfredo sauce on hand. I'm not a fan of the jar version but it's quick for my kids. I found this recipe and saw that I had all the ingredients on hand to make it. It was a time-saver and really, really good! I think next time I will use a little less milk, fresh garlic and some herbs to liven it up even more but it is just fine as it is if you're in a hurry. I will never buy the jar version again. Thank you to the OP for sharing this wonderfully easy recipe!

This was such a delicious and easy recipe. This was so good that even my super picky 7 year old daughter loved it. I did make one small change. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I did not have that much milk or cream cheese.  so here is what I did.  I used 1 can cream of mushroom, around 3 ounces of plain cream cheese, 2 ounces of cream cheese with onion and chive(I did not have enough cream cheese, but this worked out), I used a 1/4 of a cup of milk, the remainder of my Parmesan and mozzarella, which was only about a 1/4 of a cup.  I used the last of my ricotta, which was about 3 tablespoons. I blended this well and heated through, to make sure the ricotta was not grainy.  I served this over gnocchi, and it is awesome! I did add the butter and pepper, but left out the garlic powder, as the cream of mushroom had enough flavor in it!

text:
I used nonfat milk and reduced fat cream cheese, and it was soooooooo gooooood! It's perfect for those of us who lack the particular skill needed to make a roux - it truly is fool proof, a child could probably make this. Traditionally Alfredo sauce is made with Parmesan, but you can use any kind of cheese you want - I used Gruyere and it was amazing! And it great the next day too, and it made a really good cold dip too for veggies or chips or whatever. This sauce can do no wrong :)

text:
When I made this I didn't have enough cream cheese or parmesan. I used some shredded mozzarella to try and make up for it and followed the rest of the recipe pretty closely. Best homemade alfredo sauce I've ever had! I can't wait to try it again with all of the right measurements. But honestly, you can sub in any yummy white cheese and it'll probably work. For those that say they taste too much cream cheese, try some different combos or just lessen it (as I said, I didn't even have enough when I made it)! Perhaps not the most authentic Alfredo, but the tastiest and fastest in my opinion. Thanks!

Do you mean that you're supposed to actually pour this over something like  pasta? You're not supposed to just eat it as is out of the pan? Ok, I really do get it, but I love this stuff! 

I've never had alfredo chicken at OG because I'm a vegetarian and have never bought it in a jar, so can't compare, but this sauce is delicious.

I've used garlic powder in the past but today I used fresh minced garlic sauted in the butter, and I like the powder better in this recipe because it's smoother. 

I made it specifically to use in spinach/artichoke dip trying to replicate the one at Longhorn. Theirs is the best I've had...what is their secret ingredient? 

But I'm going to chop up some fresh garden tomatoes and pour it over pasta, mushrooms and tomatoes (if I don't eat it all first!)

I followed the recipe exactly except for the garlic today.

text:
We loved this!  I halved it and didn't worry too much about measurements, and still got a fantastic sauce.  Here's what I did:
Sautee 2 cloves garlic in 1T butter, add 1 T flour.
Whisk in 1 cup milk, heat through.
Add 1/2 brick cream cheese, handful of Parmesan, and pepper.
Heat until thickened.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I thought it smelled kind of like fast food, but it definitely tastes better.  My boyfriend LOVED it.  The thing I like about this recipe is that the sauce came out really smoothly, which hasn't been the case for other alfredo recipes I've tried.  I did find that I had to stir a lot initially to get the cream cheese to blend in well with the butter/garlic.

Instead of using garlic powder, I used 5 cloves of real garlic (minced).  I also added double the pepper (although I might recommend adding a whole teaspoon) and a teaspoon of oregano.  I think basil would be a nice addition as well, but I didn't have any.

Very quick, very easy, and good for the price and effort.  Not the best recipe I've had, but still really good.

text:
I made this recipe with the ingredients exactly measured.  I have made many alfredo sauces which were anywhere from fair to excellent, but all were time consuming.  This was the easiest and best home prepared alfredo I have ever made.  
My review is based on the exact recipe.
After completing the recipe I decided to make it a "creole" alfredo and add 1 1/2 tsp of Tony Chacere's Creole Seasoning.  I would give the creole version 6 stars if I could!  We used it as a sauce for baked tilapia.  We served it with fresh oven fries and a green salad.  Yummmmm.
***if you decide to make a creole version please adjust the amount of seasoning to suit your personal taste.  I would start with no more than 3/4 tsp***

text:
Wow this sauce was fabulous and SO easy! My family absolutely loved it. I doubled the recipe, and sliced up mesquite chicken breasts and tossed into the recipe after it was well blended. I stored the leftover sauce and we had it again 2 days later. Like other reviewers I highly recommend making sure it is well blended first. Because the parmesan cheese is a bit grainy you will want to make sure it is fully melted and blended. Otherwise I made this recipe exactly as written and it was perfect. This one is definitely a keeper and the family has already asked when I am going to make it again.

text:
ok, I used 4 oz. of cream cheese b/c it's all I had left.  Increased parmesan to 8+ oz. Also, sauteed 1 clove of minced garlic and 1 T. minced fresh onion in the butter before adding the cheeses. Seemed a little thin so made a slurry w/2 T. each of flour and butter which I whisked in to thicken b/c my intention was to serve over warm biscuits. Most importantly, I stirred in cooked carrots and broccoli and 3 cans of drained tuna. Guess you could call it Tuna Alfredo over biscuits! Delicious!

text:
This is a great alfredo sauce if you are short for time and/or cooking impaired.  I can mess up any recipe, but this one turns out well every time.  

I use less butter than it calls for and buy the flavored cream cheese (the garlic flavored is awesome in this).  I also use 2% milk.  

Toss the sauce with some of the refrigerated or frozen cheese tortellini, some peas and bacon/ham/pancetta and you have a great meal!

region:

country:
None
text:
I needed an Alfredo sauce to make something and I figured with so many great reviews this had to be good.  I wasn't disappointed.

Two minor, minor alterations when I made it though: 
I used fresh garlic rather than garlic powder (it's worth the 2 extra minutes of effort, just make sure you cook the garlic long enough to cut the sharpness before adding the milk), and 
I used white pepper (since Alfredo sauce is white, it's just more aesthetically pleasing).
Awesome recipe though, will definitely be making this again soon.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I LOVE this recipe. I've been making it for so long. My entire family asks me to make this so they can come over and have dinner. I have it about once a week and my boyfriend NEVER gets tired of it. I did make a few changes. I use minced garlic instead of powder, I use half heavy cream and half milk (I just started doing that, is still fantastic with just milk) I lowered the amount of milk added because we all like thick sauce. I also use a block of parm that I grate myself instead of the already shredded kind, makes it so much yummier. I also use a lot more Parmesan than called for. When I first made this sauce exactly how it was written out, it was still awesome. I just added and subtracted a few things as I make it. I believe I have it perfect! 
Thanks for this recipe!

It is not a restaurant quality sauce but for being done in 10 min, it's tastes really good! It is a bit grainy, but still the taste makes up for that.
I sauteed the garlic for a minute in the butter and didn't put as much milk as it reached a perfect thickness with only half a cup or so.
Definitely recommended for working moms who want to serve a tasty dinner in an instant

text:
This was really good for a quick alfredo sauce! It didn't taste authentic to me but it was quick, easy and used up the ingredients I had in the house. I normally make a recipe using heavy cream and never tried the cream cheese before. The sauce was creamy and it didn't taste the cream cheese. I used 2% milk and ended up adding a little more at the end to thin it out slightly. I served it over penne because that is what I had in the house and it was still very satisfying.

userID:

Display Name:
BELINDADUVESSA
isPro:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've used this for years as it's always worked well for me.  The only problem I have noticed it after you refrigerate it, it doesn't really heat back up well.  It's not horrible but definitely not the same consistency as when you poured it over the pasta.  Also, it develops more of a cream cheese look after it's been refrigerated.  If you mix it directly with the pasta and plan to have any leftovers, keep this in mind.  It might be better to store the sauce separately from the pasta if you plan on using some of it later.  A good recipe, just the storing and later usage is the only issue I had with it.....and that could have just been me.

Anyways, for taste, I highly recommend this.  You can also use shredded Parmesean, if you have any of that lying around.  I've also substituted a 4 cheese Italian blend and it turned out well, with a slightly milder taste.

text:
Quick and delicious!  I used it over a box of whole wheat pasta I was needing to get out of my pantry because my family HATES the whole wheat pasta.  They actually LOVED this!  They didn't even gripe about the pasta...not one comment!  They actually said they LIKED dinner!!  Score!    I used 1 TBSP jarred, minced garlic instead of powder because that's what I had.  I also had a half box of some sliced, fresh mushrooms I needed to use before they went bad.  So I sauted (sp?) them with the butter before adding the rest of the ingredients and made it more of an Alfredo/mushroom sauce.   I did double the pepper and added some salt to taste.    This may not be a super gourmet sauce, but I will keep this recipe for a fast cream sauce I know my family will actually eat!!!!

country:
None
text:
Definitely a go-to recipe! 2nd time making this. 1st time it was too rich & I had to thin it out w/ water. Everyone still raved about it. This time around I wanted more of a garlic butter cream sauce. Sauteed shrimp, chicken sausage, roma tomatoes, & bella mushrooms in (approx 1 1/4 cup) EVOO (instead of butter) w/ 1tbsp of minced garlic. Added 1/2 pack of cream chz, approx 1/4 cup of shredded parmesan, romano & asagio chz & 2tbsp of grated parmesan. Reduced with some white wine & voila!! Tossed with angel hair pasta & it was perfect.   *All measurements are approximate due to the fact that I rarely measure when cooking.

userID:
4186217
Display Name:
Timothy Donnelly
isPro:

0

1

33
recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1241530.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a good recipe (with alterations), but it is not alfredo sauce.  No matter what any other review says you can taste the sourness from the cream cheese.  Yes it is smooth, yes it is cheesy, yes it is good, but it is not IMHO as good as a heavy or light cream based alfredo.  When I make this again (which I will) I will probably use it as a topping to fish or chicken where the sourness plays better instead of against pasta.  I would NEVER put this with shrimp.  The sourness would dominate the delicate taste of the shrimp.

country:
None
text:
This is a good base recipe, but it was missing something.  Mine stayed milky when it was supposed to thicken up and didn't have enough flavor so I added 1/2 T dried parsley, 1/4 C white wine, and a few tbsps of flour (to get it to thicken up).  I also used garlic salt instead of garlic powder. I would recommend buying good parmesan and grating it yourself. Before making these changes, it was bland and runny.  With the changes I would give it 5 stars!

text:
Awesome, tasty, easy recipe!! So convenient and way tastier than any jarred sauce.  Its easier to blend when the cream cheese is room temperature or either warmed in the microwave that way you're not adding cold cream cheese to warm butter...also, try warming the milk for easier combining.  I used some fresh garlic in addition and also some parsley.  Perfect!! Will def keep this around to make over and over.

text:
We didn't really like this sauce. It was simple enough to make, though I wouldn't call it "quick" considering how long it took for the cream cheese to melt in, despite cutting it up a bit first. The sauce, however, was much too rich and creamy for our liking. The taste was VERY rich and it was so creamy that the texture was almost pasty. I even used light cream cheese. Oh, and I used 1 tsp minced garlic instead of the garlic powder. My two-year-old son refused to eat this altogether, and my husband and I felt sick to our stomachs after doing so. I won't be making this again. Thanks anyway!

text:
After reading all the reviews I decided to try this out as-directed first. And let me just say: AMAZING!!! The only did 2 things differently, I used Smart Balance Spread instead of butter (i try not to use butter or margarine), and I added a pinch of Greek Seasoning. I was afraid this would be too liquidy or too cream cheesy, but after simmering it for a few minutes, it was perfect! My boyfriend and I loved it so much I even froze some to use later!  In the future I'd definitely use fresh garlic instead of garlic powder -- if it was this amazing with garlic powder I can't wait to have it with the real deal!!

text:
This was pretty good. I don't like my sauce so sweet so I used 4 oz cream cheese, but it was still noticably sweet. I used half and half instead of milk and used only 1 cup. I also used fresh chopped parsley in the sauce and basil on the top as I served it I served this on fresh sauteed fish. I first sauteed onions, garlic and sweet red and green peppers untill tender. Add some sundried tomatoes and heat through. keep warm. Then I sauteed the fish. Top the fish with the veges and then the Alfredo sauce, then add the basil and some sundried tomatoes for color. Beautiful!

country:

text:
Incredible is the only way I can describe this sauce. I think this every bit as good of any Alfredo sauce that you can get at a 4 star restaurant. When melting the better I took 2 large cloves of garlic and grated into the butter. I used 1 cup no fat milk and one cup of cream.  Penzey's Italian spice (1tbsp.)  Fresh ground black pepper. My partner is a very good chef/cook of italian foods, and he loves it. I would highly recommend this recipe to anyone attempting Alfredo for the first time.  Just remember to take you time and not try to rush with high heat etc.

text:
I made this tonight for my fiancé’ and he absolutely loved it. I’m rather new to the cooking world, but I’m trying to polish my skills for my soon to be “wife” role. I think this recipe will be one of my staples. I didn’t really measure anything but I think this recipe is pretty versatile. I use both olive oil and butter, used minced garlic instead of garlic powder, and I used parmesan and mozzarella cheese as well as cream cheese. I also cooked scallops before hand and threw them in when the Alfredo was finished. This recipe was a great tool in helping me create a fantastic easy dinner that I’m sure I’ll continue to make for years.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Not a huge fan of alfredo but this looked so easy I had to try it for my son, who loves noodles. It is easy enough to even do in the micorwave. Make sure cream cheese is room temp. The flavor is not too bad if you doctor it up to hide the cream cheese flavor. I used garlic and added oregano. I added quite a bit more milk. It got way too thick for me. Absolutely use fresh Parmesan. And make sure it is grated not shredded. The shredded will clump together into a ball. The grated will disperse into the sauce better.

None
text:
So easy and delicious.  The family liked it. I only made half, plenty for 4 people. I used 1% milk and light cream cheese to cut down on calories and cholesterol, and a little less parmesan to cut down on the salt.  It took a little longer to thicken but so yummy, especially with the garlic powder and  freshly ground pepper.  Next time I may try it with a cholesterol-lowering margarine, although I hesitate to mess with the buttery flavour...I also might try it with shredded Italian 6-cheese blend.  I also like the idea someone else had of using this as a base sauce with mushroom, fresh basil, sun-dried tomatoes etc.  I used this over veggies as well as pasta, and even mixed it with some canned diced Italian tomatoes and browned ground turkey to make a creamy tomato sauce. Versatile!

text:
This recipe isn't necessarily quicker than "normal" alfredo sauce, but I almost NEVER have heavy cream in the fridge, so this recipe works great for me! I use 1/3 less fat cream cheese and skim milk and it turns out really good, and I ALWAYS leave out the garlic powder. I like to saute a zucchini, a yellow squash, and some fresh garlic in a little olive oil and chop up a few tomatoes and add them to the pasta and sauce. Yum! I've made this sauce recipe many times, and it all turns out great.

text:
This recipe was great because I had all the ingredients available - and it allowed for easy modification to make it my own. I used 1 T of minced garlic instead of the powder to the basic recipe. Then, after it was heated, I added two slices provolone cheese, two cubed chicken breasts and a half-pound of left-over baby bella mushrooms that I had sauteed in butter, onions, and garlic.   It didn't come out as creamy as some alfredos, but I like that the sauce remained saucy (instead of paste) as it got cooler in my plate while I was eating.

Loved this recipe. I added onion and garlic. I substituted part of the milk with half and half (and didn't use 2 full cups of liquid)and added less cream cheese, and maybe a dash more Parmesan. The asiago addition is a great idea and I may try that next time. I also served (pasta, of course and)chicken breasts, which I first browned in EVOO, then added onion, garlic, salt, pepper and fresh basil leaves on a low simmer. My 13-year-old son was crazy over this recipe and he's a picky eater.

text:
Like others, I cut the amount of butter to 3/4 of the original quantity. I also used 1/3 fat cream cheese, and skim milk. It turned out very well, but you can definitely tell it is made with garlic powder - yuck. Next time I will use fresh garlic. I didn't have any this time, unfortunately.   I put the Parmesan cheese in before the milk so it would melt... I hate the gritty texture.   I also added oregano and nutmeg, and will add even more next time. This is great and easy!  Finally, this makes a TON of sauce. I cut the recipe down to two servings and it still made enough for at least 3.

text:
An excellent, quick alfredo sauce.  Adjust the amount of cream cheese to your personal tastes, and the result will be a perfect alfredo sauce!  I use about 4 oz. cream cheese with 6 oz. parmesan.  Also, I mellow out the flavor with a small handful of shredded mozzarella.  Don't add too much or your sauce WILL turn rubbery. Very, very tasty!!

text:
Easy Peasy...Thats what I'm talking about. Being a working parent of an active family could not have an easier supper meal. The whole family loved it. It has an incredible flavor. I did sub. the garlic powder and chopped up 2 small garlic cloves and sauted with the butter. Also, putting in sea salt and a good heaping of oregano, 1 can drained mushroom and whatever forzen vegys you have in the freezer if you like. I had broccoli, carrots, califlower mix makes this dish irresitable. Grilled chicken gives it that extra flavor for the best alfredo sauce ever.....

I made this last night and it was so easy and so yummy, way better than store bought bottled alfredo sauce. I did make a few alterations...While melting the butter and the cream cheese I added a garlic clove cut in half and then reduced the garlic powder to 1 tsp. text:
I thought this recipe was great! It was really easy to make because it uses common household items (Like cream cheese instead of whipping cream, or half & half). The only draw back is, everytime I make this, it seems to be too runny. I don't think I'm leaving on the stovetop too long, but I might be, who knows. Anyways, If this happens to you, a quick fix is to use a quick mix flour (Like a sauce thickener for gravy). It helps tons!

I LOVED this sauce!  It tasted great, and totally fooled my foodie date.  I put it in a lasagna so I wasn't too worried about the consistency.  The cream cheese didn't really break down and melt all the way though.  If I had been making it for a fettuccine or something, I just would have run the immersion blender it is for a bit, and it would have been perfect!  It does not taste jarred at all, unlike what some other reviewers had to say.  Jarred sauce is disgusting.  Make sure you use regular cream cheese, and not low fat.

I am giving this 5 Stars, I am sure it would have been extremely fabulous if I had followed the recipe. Had all the ingredients out to use, I thought. I was tempering the butter and cream cheese. My husband interrupted me, telling me "I had to go to Home Depot for him to get light bulbs for a ceiling fan he was installing." (Home Depot sold him the wrong lights) We have all heard a variation on that story. (Smiles)  When I returned I started cooking everything. The aroma was wonderful, consistancy was the pitts. Maybe I should check the amounts of ingredients, before I start, everything was right except for the butter. I had doubled the amount of butter. Oh Well, add some more milk, after fixing all my mistakes. It came out tasting great, consistancy wasn't what I wanted. Poured sauce over Bow Tie Noodles, Served with Butterfly Pork Chops, Italian Mixed Veggies, Italian Garlic Bread and a Chardony Wine. (Moral to this review while cooking. Don't run errands for your husband while trying to fix dinner.) The next time I make this I will make sure I have all the correct amounts ready to go. Thanks for a great recipe.   I have 2 Saint Bernards (200 pounds each) that stay in the kitchen with me while I cook, they are no trouble at all, they just lay there waiting for Mom to drop goodies.(Smiles) Peggy BigDogsMom

text:
After eating @ an italian restaurant this past wknd, I wanted to duplicate the amazing meal we had. Tortellini in alfredo sauce with prosciutto. I will say, I think my meal was as good if not better than theirs. I tripled the recipe (big family), & added minced garlic, otherwise, made exactly as recipe indicates. It made a huge batch. The only thing I'd do differently is cut down on the butter, especially if I triple the batch. It was plenty rich on it's own. I may add peas or asparagus to it next time with the prosciutto. Add some candles, a glass of wine and some bread and you just created a very romantic getaway to Italy. YES, it's that good!   UPDATE: made this a second time & used diced, store bought, pre-cooked chicken & added broccoli that I had partially steamed. Again, very yummy. This is a nice basic recipe for the sauce. You can snazz it up any way you'd like.

text:
This was an excellent recipe.  However, it makes a lot of sauce.  The listed 4 serving size would be a very large serving.  I measured the amount of sauce, and there was about 6 cups of sauce with this recipe.  I used about 1/4 cup of sauce on my noodles (1 1/4 cup) and chicken, and it was very saucy.  It is a very rich sauce so a little is very filling.  I will definitely make this again, but I will make a half recipe.  I used reduced fat cream cheese, skim milk, and only 3/4 stick of margarine.  It was great.

text:
Wow!  This alfredo sauce is absolutely scrumptious and oh-so-simple to make!  No hint of a cream cheese taste at all.  I threw in a teaspoon of minced garlic with the butter while it melted, then added 1/2 a teaspoon of garlic powder with the milk.  For the parmesan is used part shredded and part grated parm/ramano combo.  The result was perfect!  I served it over fettucine with cubed pre-cooked chicken thrown into the mix (a great time-saver!).  YUM!!  Thanks for sharing :)

text:
I loved this recipe!  The sauce was creamy and flavorful, even with the lower calorie changes I made.  I used a stick of 50/50 butter and Omega3 spread, reduced calorie cream cheese, 1 1/2c. skim milk, and 4oz of freshly grated aged parm.  I agree with other posters that whisking the butter and cream cheese was key, as was adding the milk slowly.  I didn't have any issues with lumps, and my hubs was impressed!  This will be my alfredo recipe from now on.

text:
After reading the reviews, I had some changes I wanted to try, but I decided to follow the recipe closely the first time to get an idea of how it's supposed to taste before I change it up.  This recipe makes a very delicious alfredo sauce that was a big hit with my husband.  The calorie content makes me cringe, though, so I'm going to try cutting the butter in half next time.  I'll also reduce the milk by about a half cup, since the sauce was a bit thin and required some extra cooking time to thicken.  I'd also like to experiment with other spices (oregano, italian seasoning, and nutmeg).  I will definitely make this sauce again.

text:
Yummy!  I didn't have any cream or half and half so I decided to give this sauce a try for our Shrimp Fettucini tonight.  It was delicious!  It definitely does not have a strong cream cheese flavor, which was my main worry.  My only complaint was that it was still a little 'chunky' even after melting together on low and slowly adding the ingredients (I did use 1/3 less fat cream cheese).  But the lumpy texture is not that noticable because your busy shoveling it into your mouth!  We topped the pasta, sauce and shrimp with diced tomatoes... great meal.

text:
Very very good! My sister and I loved this recipe. I added a few things to make it even better. I cut up 2 small chicken breasts, I added a small container of fresh mushrooms and then used about half of a small onion in tiny pieces and fried it all together. Then while boiling the pasta I added some frozen broccoli florets to the water. It truly tasted like something from a fine restaurant. I had a lot left over so I put it all in a large bowl and in the fridge. I honestly didn't expect it to heat up well the next day but I microwaved it and it was just as good  as the night before. Very creamy and no milk needed.  Cant ask for a easier Alfredo sauce!

Pretty good. I've never been a huge Alfredo fan but I made this thinking my toddler might like it (I didn't find out: he refused to even try it. Sigh. He's SUCH a two year old.), and I ended up eating his meal for dinner tonight. I made it with less butter than the recipe called for, reduced fat milk, and I had unfortunately run out of milk earlier so I just used half and half I had in the fridge for the recipe. If I make this again I would definitely use our standard 1% milk, because this was really a very heavy and rich dish.

text:
This recipe is INCREDIBLE!!!! I am a HUGE fan. WOW. The only thing I suggest is to maybe use 1/2 or 3/4 of the butter. This is definitely restaurant worthy; but whips up pretty quick. I also added a pinch of nutmeg, and didn't notice it. Day two: Refrigerates and reheats well on the stove. So-so in the microwave.  It made so much sauce that we were dipping out carrots in it just so it wouldn't go to waste (made a nice carrot dip too)! End: try the sauce. If you like alfredo you won't be disappointed.

text:
i'm giving this 5 stars because my kids said it's the best meal they have had in a long time eventhough i made blackeye peas, sweet homemade cornbread, greens, smoked turkey tails homemade mac and cheese and sweet candied yams the day before yesterday and i know they love that stuff. i would give it 4 stars because i knew off the back that 8 ounces would be too much cream cheese so i only used 4oz and i still could taste it but it was good! i did use half and half and heavy cream but not the milk and about a half tsp of flour to ensure thickness because of other reviews complaints of the sauce being too thin. i also used some minced garlic along with the garlic powder and i used dried parsley for the color. i will make this again but with more changes because it's so fattening and you could still see the butter after it cooled down so i'll definatly will cut that in half. my son said did you use butter in it cause i can taste it and i used about a tbls less than the recipe called for. i never bought real parmesan so i used the stuff in the plastic bottle grated parmesan and it worked out well.  all in all it is a good recipe and i will be making this again soon.

city:

country:
None
text:
Whoa - as many have indicated, this alfredo sauce is quick easy and incredible. I also used skim milk and light cream cheese - I did not cut the milk amount down (as others indicated) because I wanted to stretch out the calories/fat from the parmesean also, so I added a teaspoon of cornstarch to compensate for the watery-ness of the skim milk. It worked PERFECTLY. So delicious, so satisfying, just as good or better than the sauces you get at these gourmet restaurants.   The only reason this fell short of five stars, was because of my tweaking. I like my sauce high on flavor, so I cut up an onion, added 1 tbsp of minced garlic (instead of garlic powder), nutmeg, oregano, and some cajun seasoning. I also battered and baked some eggplant to put on top - which just made this dish perfection

This is a good recipe!  I did make some changes based on what I had in the pantry.  I used 1 teaspoon garlic pepper instead of the garlic powder followed by black pepper.  I also thought that the parmesan does not blend as well as you would expect.  It turns out somewhat grainy, but it gives it a unique texture that is still good.  I will definately give it another shot though!

text:
I was given a recipe very similar to this one, several years ago.  Mine doesn't add the garlic powder (which I will try next time!!); has only 1/2 cup milk; and calls for 1 cup of parmesan cheese (which I cut down to 3/4 cup).  I add parsley for some color.  I have made this with low fat and fat free cream cheese, and you can't tell the difference!!  We are just 2, and this makes a perfect amount for 8oz of pasta.  It is so good, that we never order alfredo at restaurants any more cuz it is NEVER as good. LOL

None
country:
None
text:
This is not only quick and easy, but very delicious. It got rave reviews from my family as well! For those who are wondering about how the cream cheese works with this recipe, you can't even detect that it is an ingredient, it adds a wonderful creaminess to the sauce though. I used half skim milk and half cream. Stir occasionally to prevent lumps from forming, sauce will thicken as it cooks and as it cools. Season to taste and you'll have the perfect alfredo sauce. Wonderful creation Sarah, thanks so much for sharing.

text:
I looked up a recipe for my sister to use for a dinner party and saw this great review. I helped her and her friend make the sauce and I had them use 1 cup 2 percent milk and 1 cup heavy cream to make it slightly creamier and thicker. I also had them use 3 small to medium cloves of garlic, pressed and sautéed. The sauce does have a cream cheese taste to it so if you don't like cream cheese this really isn't a sauce for you. The second time my sister tried to make it she made it by herself and supposably followed the recipe completely. It was very garlicy and did not even have the same texture.

This is absolutely delicious!  I will make this every time since I always seem to have the ingredients around.  Changes made were: I used only 7 T. of butter instead of 1/2 c.  I think you could even get away with only using 1/3 c. butter. Only used 1 1/3 c. milk. Used minced fresh garlic and sauteed in butter instead of the powder.  Added a few shavings of fresh nutmeg.  This was the easiest sauce I've made.  It makes quite a bit and the leftovers would be deicious over some cheese tortellini.  Enjoy!

Fantastic! I used minced garlic in place of powder, added a bit of salt and whisked away! The sauce thickened up quickly. I used about half parmesan from the bag, and half from the plastic jar. Alter the ingredients to taste, this sauce is foolproof. You couldn't even tell there was cream cheese in it. A very yummy, easy sauce. Nothing like the alfredo in the jar. I served this over gnocchi to rave reviews. I highly recommend this recipe!

This was pretty good. I don't think I'll make it too often simply because it isn't very healthy. Although I did cut the butter in half and use low fat cream cheese. I also only used about half of the milk, used minced garlic instead of powder, added a little chopped onion, and instead of just parmesan used an Italian cheese blend. Served over penne. I had it two days later and it was excellent!**

jamiek

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great and easy like it says! This is a great base sauce! I have now made this recipe several times and it always a hit.  I used low fat cream cheese and low fat milk. It was also great when we subbed some of the parmesan for asiago. I add thinly sliced red and yellow peppers and cherry tomatos sliced in half that I saute first. I saute the peppers and then when they are about done I add the tomatos for a minute and then add everything to the competed sauce and then let it simmer for a few mintutes or until everyone is ready to eat. I also add a dash of cajun seasoning to give it a little spice and a pinch of crushed red pepper or a little basil depending on how I want the sauce to taste. I have also added baby spinach, stir in and let it cook for a minute or until spinach begins to wilt and then serve. Yummy! It always turns out great. I serve it over bowtie pasta and it looks really pretty with the peppers and tomatos.

text:
This was definitely very quick and very easy, and the taste was really good (creamy and cheesy.)  I halved the recipe and it still made plenty for two for dinner and two servings for lunches the next day.  I added a little more fresh ground pepper than called for, a little parsley, and a dash of nutmeg.  Family really enjoyed it.  I think it would still be as delicious with using only half the called for amount of butter.  The butter and cream cheese mixture did not come together immediately, but I kept whisking and adding the milk slowly and the texture came out perfectly (just be careful not to splatter hot butter on yourself!)  Will make again and again.

country:
None
text:
A couple of observations - definitely use a good quality parmesan that you shred yourself as the Kraft type just doesn't melt correctly.  Also, I saute mushrooms and chicken breast (1" pieces) together and add it with the pasta when I toss to coat in the sauce.  Then add a bit of reserved shredded parm on top.  My family loves it and it is special enough for company.  Oh, I use fresh garlic instead of powder, I mince enough for a heaping tblsp, you can add to taste though.  Enjoy!

text:
Made this today with a few changes. I added 1tbsp of minced garlic and some garlic salt. Used  only 2 ozs of butter, 10 ozs of evaporated milk and about 2-3ozs of parmesan cheese.Like another reviewer I softened the cream cheese before using and slowly whisked everything together. This sauce came together very quickly, was smooth and just the right consistency. ***Delicious***

I have a different recipe for alfredo, but couldn't find it.  This was the closest that I could come to mine....this was MUCH better!  Mine always seemed too greasy (butter) and never mixed into a smooth mixture.  I will use this again and again from now on!!!

text:
This was an *insanely* delicious base sauce.  I added a preliminary step by sauteing: onions, crimini mushrooms & garlic (seasoned with salt & pepper)and then, I made the sauce mixed with that.  I also took the advice of reviewers & added nutmeg & fresh parsley.  I lighten up the recipe & used 1/3 fat cream cheese, smart butter & added 2% milk slowly to control the consistency - it was plenty rich & creamy.  I put it over penne & brocc also mix it up with some leftover salmon.

text:
Oh my gracious! This was the most unbelievable recipe that I have ever used for homemade Alfredo Sauce!  In my opinion it is very close in flavor to Olive Gardens.  It was so easy to make.  I use shredded parmesan cheese instead of grated.  It was a little lumpy at first, but melted nicely.  It does thinken after it sits, but we re-heated it the next day and I added a little milk and it revived it totally!  I also use one cup half n half and one cup milk instead on 2 cups milk.  I will never use store bought alfredo sauce again.

text:
This was absolutely wonderful!  I cooked dinner for 2 more people than normal and I usually just buy the Knorr Alfredo Sauce packet and spice it up myself...well - with all the extra pasta 2 packets just wasn't enough.  I didn't have the cream called for in most recipes, but plenty of cream cheese - your sauce was wonderful, more tasty, and simple.  AND it saved my dinner!  The only alteration was instead of the garlic powder which I didn't have, I used Johnnys Garlic Spread & Seasoning (Made by the Johnnys Seasoning people)  I was a bit worried at first, but it's fantastic!  Definately a keeper!

userID:
2865177
Display Name:
wonderwoman-juzkiddin
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
122
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674169.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We loved it although I did change it just a bit by adding the Kroger version of Mrs. Dash to it.  I used it in a ham/alfredo pizza recipe. Really tasty for a different type of pizza using left over holiday ham.

Make the sauce rather thick by adding extra parmesan cheese.
Spread on pizza crust (adding your favorite spices to your specific tastes may be advisable)
cut-up ham 
chopped green and red pepper
chopped red onion
mushrooms (which ever type is your fav.  we like portabella and cremini)
top with mozzarella and or your fav. pizza cheese.  ( I would like to try it with Asiago cheese, but have not yet.  Bet it would be tasty.)
Cook according to your pizza crust package directions with a possible few extra minutes pending on how high your pizza is from all the yummy ingrediants.
I'm thinking about adding some banana peppers or green olives on my next pizza. Maybe even some spinache would be good.

I have used fat-free cream cheese and skim milk to cut-down on fat and calories.

Cut original sauce recipe in half to accomodate one 12" pizza.  Hope all else try and enjoy this recipe as we do!
Review:

5

This recipe is great, and so simple to make. The quality and taste is maybe even better than what you would expect to find in a good Italian restaurant. It is very rich and full of flavor, and we used light cream cheese and skim milk to lighten up the fat and calories. You can add whatever you like- parsley, basil, shrimp, chicken- so many possibilities! Thanks for this great recipe.

text:
I made this tonight and it was so easy and good.  I used two cloves of garlic because I did not have the powder, and because I had just a tub of cream cheese (16oz) I eye-balled half of that for the requisite 8oz.  I also had no idea how much 6oz of parmesan looked like - so I just grated it over the sauce and guessed.  It was awesome.  My husband - who is used to plain old spaghetti or mac and cheese (b/c of kids) was so thrilled that I actually cooked - AND I added scallops which were frozen in the bag.  I sauteed them first before adding to sauce.  I guess I could have cooked them in the sauce but I am so scared of raw everything!!!  Anyway - I loved it.  My husband was thrilled.  The kids didn't eat it - but they never eat dinner so who cares!!  Thanks!

I made this tonight with some small changes: used Neufchatel (the 1/3 less fat cream cheese), half whole + half 1% milk, and garlic salt instead of garlic powder.  I added some cajun smoked salmon with spinach fettucine.  A little bit of fresh grated parmesan on top with a side salad made a complete meal.  My husband is VERY picky about his cream sauces, and he LOVED this one!  We will be making this regularly!

I tried this for the first time last nite.  It is quick to make and turns out yummy and very rich.  My boyfriend is a pastaholic and he loved it. Out of this world.  A secret to this is saute some uncooked shrimp in the butter and garlic first, reserve the shrimp then add once sauce is complete.  Also add a bit of cajan spice to kick it up.  for those that had issues with it not thickening, just use a TBLS of Corn starch and some cold milk and make a slurry then add to sauce once boiling. works perfect.

text:
To be honest, just reading the ingredients I was a little unsure of this recipe, but I thought I would give it a try since it seemed so simple.  Im glad I decided to! Im not a fan of alfredo in general, the dh is, but boy am I a fan of this! Its fantastic! You can't even taste the cream cheese! Its SUPER! I did make a few changes.  I sauteed garlic and mushrooms with a bit of olive oil, salt and black pepper. Then I cooked chicken breasts sliced into strips.  I removed the chicken and mushrooms but left the liquid from cooking in the pan.  I made the sauce as the recipe calls for, only I used homogenized milk, added some more black pepper and garlic salt.  I also think the next time I make this, and I will definitely be making it again, I will add roasted red peppers! Mmmm... WONDERFUL!

text:
I was in a pinch one evening and needed a quick recipe for alfredo sce, using things I had on hand.  This is the most delicious alfredo sauce I've ever eaten.  I make it in batches and keep it in jars in the fridge to have on hand during the week.  We use it as dipping sauce for garlic bread, too.  It's so much better than anything you would find in a restaurant.  The only change I made was I used less garlic powder than called for.  It's fantastic w/the 2tbs, but my husband isn't a huge fan of that much garlic.  THANK YOU for this easy recipe!!!

region:

country:
None
text:
I used fresh pressed garlic (and lots of it), garlic seasoned grilled chicken and spinach.  It added that extra flavour that sends it over the top. I also use low fat cream cheese, half the butter and 1% milk to cut down the fat content.
It is nearly impossible to get the cream cheese smooth before adding the milk,  but it will still turn out very smooth once the milk is added. We make a doulbe batch and freeze the sauce into dinner size portions, it tastes even better after all the flavours have had time to blend.

This is THE BEST alfredo sauce ever!  I used 2 fresh garlic cloves in place of the powder, and it still turned out terrific.  The thickness can be adjusted relatively simply.....we like our alfredo sauce a bit on the thick side so I only added 1 cup of milk- but if you like it thinner, definately add at least 1 & 1/2 cups milk.  Thanks so much for sharing this recipe! :)

text:
WOW!  I didnt think that there really could be a homemade Alfredo sauce that tastes as good as this one!  I used fresh garlic-3 cloves smashed and diced- I put the buter, cream cheese, milk and garlic in all at the same time and used a whisk to mix all together. then when at a low simmer I added the parmesan cheese.  The only parm I had though was the grated stuff from kraft. I had no prob using that cheese!

text:
I made this for my family, and the keds really loved it, even my picky daughter who generally doesn't like alfredo.  I made it according to directions, except I used minced garlic instead of granulated, and I added about 1/3 of a 28-oz can of tomato puree to make a tomato alfredo (haven't been able to find a decent recipe for that!).  It turned out wonderful!  However, it didn't thicken up much while it was cooking, but it did while it cooled.  We will definitely make this one again... and again.

text:
I'm VERY glad I read the reviews of this before I tried it out. Otherwise, when the butter and the cream cheese didn't blend well, I'd have panicked.  This recipe was extremely easy to make, but had a flavor that wasn't exactly "alfredo".  It's not that it tasted like cream cheese, it just wasn't quite the traditional flavor I'd anticipated.  Once I mixed it with the pasta and my other ingredients, it was fine, and my kids loved it.  But for those of you who taste test while cooking, just be aware that it may not be exactly as you expected.

text:
This was so good! I cut back a bit on the butter - used 6 T instead of 8. Next time I'll cut back some more. I also had 1/2 cup of cream, so I used that plus 1 cup of skim milk instead of using 2 cups milk (glad I did that or it would have been way too runny). I also used fresh minced garlic which was wonderful. I didn't have fresh parmesan and didn't have bad results using the packaged powdery stuff. Also used reduced fat cream cheese. I sauteed some shrimp, chicken, broccoli and mushrooms and added that to the sauce and served over penne - what a great meal.

text:
This is my "old standby" recipe.  My whole family (including my very picky 3 year old) loves it.  I love that it doesn't seperate like most Alfredo suaces when refrigerated, and it is just as good the next day.  This recipe makes plenty for lunch the next day.  I bought a plastic wisk specifically for this recipe, I make it so often.  Just be careful when wisking the butter, I tend to get butter splatters on me so I have to remember to wear an apron!  This is one of the best Alfredo sauces we have ever had and it's so easy.  I will try adding nutmeg next time, but I can't imagine it getting any better!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My son-in-law makes alfredo sauce using heavy cream instead of the milk and cream cheese.  The taste of his sauce is the same, but it is heavier.  I tried this recipe and prefer the cream cheese and milk.

I also agree that the amount of milk this recipe calls for is a bit too much.  The sauce comes a bit on the thin side (but still tastes delicious!).  I solved that problem by adding a tiny bit of corn starch (flour will do the trick as well).

I think I am going to try this recipe next time using low fat cream cheese.  If the taste is the same, I will continue to use it instead of the regular cream cheese.

Quick and easy recipe.  I will be adding this one to my collection!

5

This has to be the easiest and cheapest way to make your own alfredo sauce and it tastes great! text:
I've always used a package mix to make my alfredo sauce and was hoping that by taking the extra effort to make the sauce from scratch it would taste as wonderful as the reviews made it out to be; however, even though it was relatively easy to make and had a nice creamy consistency, my entire family did not like the overwhelming taste the cream cheese gave this recipe. I guess it just depends on what kind of flavor you are used to - and this was not it.  If I were to make this recipe again, I would only use half of the cream cheese.

I had my doubts about this recipe and how it would turn out but it was amazing. A couple of people said that it tastes just like the alfredo sauce at the Olive Garden and they weren't kidding! I had about a half cup of whipping cream in my fridge that I added & then I added about 2 more oz of cheese & a bit of corn starch because the cream thinned the sauce. It tastes amazing. I put half in the fridge for tomorrow! I will definately make this again!

We loved this recipe, it was so simple and easy. I did make a couple changes. I added a tad of nutmeg to it to give it some zing. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband liked it, but I thought it was very cream cheesy tasting.  When I added the cheese, there was about 1 minute when the mix turned slimy and stretched out on the spoon.  I was concerned it was ruined!  But I kept cooking, and within another minute or two, the cheese melted and it was a wonderful consistency.  I used an electric mixer to make it very smooth before serving and remove a couple of lumps.  I will probably make again, but will only use about half as much cream cheese so it does not dominate the flavor.  I added a little lemon juice and nutmeg to try to change the flavor, but it still tasted like melted cream cheese to me.

text:
It came out ok. It was grainy and very thick (ricotta cheese type thick),but I think it was my fault.I think I added a little too much cream cheese. The flavor itself was good,just not the texture. I used fat free cream cheese,half fat free milk and half fat free half&half,and shredded parmesan/romano cheese. I also took the advice of some people and cooked some minced garlic in the butter in the begining and I parcooked some pasta and put it in a casserole dish. I cooked it at 350 degrees for 10 minutes. I added some cubed cooked ham for added texture and salt.I ended up tossing it out only because it was toooooo thick and grainy. The taste was good enough to attempt to try it again next time. Hopefully, with better results in regards to the texture.  :-)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The best and easiest sauce ever! Will never buy bottled nor prepackaged sauce again.  I used minimal margarine, lowfat cream cheese and milk.  I parcooked the pasta. Placed it in a casserole dish with the sauce. Baked it covered for about 10 minutes at 350 degrees.  If the sauce gets too thick add a little more milk and margarine and place back in the oven. Sprinkled more cheese on top when serving.  My family was thrilled.  Will definitely make again and again. Thanks Dawn for sharing the recipe!

This was the best alfredo sauce I have ever made; better than most restaurants.  I too used 1 cup heavy cream and 1 cup milk.  I used fresh chopped garlic, red bell pepper and green onions which were sauted in the butter.  For spices I substituted garlic pepper for the pepper.  Also added shredded broiled chicken breasts.  Thank You!

text:
The Alfredo sauce tasted really good! It was fast and easy. I used 1 cup milk and 1 cup heavy whipping cream and cut back on the garlic. It turned out rather nice...however you have to stir constantly so the sauce won't burn. For a great meal...use the recipe on this site for the Italian chicken marinade and grill the chicken to top the pasta. For an even faster meal, grill the chicken using a "George Foreman" type of grill. FAST, EASY and DELICIOUS!
